questions.text: Identify the stage of senile cataract depicted in the given image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the characteristic appearance of Morgagnian hypermature cataract.

Morgagnian hypermature cataract is characterized by the liquefaction of the entire cortex. The lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid. The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, its position altering with a change in the position of the head.

Senile Cataract

Types:

  • Cortical (soft cataract): 75%   
  • Nuclear (hard cataract): 25%

Cortical cataract is further divided into the cuneiform and cupuliform types.

Cuneiform (70%) Posterior subcapsular/Cupuliform (5%)

Radial spoke-like opacity starting in the periphery and extending centrally

Central saucer-shaped opacity in the posterior cortex just below the capsule

Late visual loss

Early loss of visual acuity
 

Most visually handicapping senile cataract 

 

Nuclear cataract

  • Pigmented nuclear cataracts: Due to the deposition of urochrome pigment
    • Catarata brunescens
    • Catarata nigra
    • Catarata rubra

Related Pearl: Maturation of Cortical Cataract

1. Stage of lamellar separation 

2. Stage of incipient cataract- cuneiform and cupuliform patterns can be made out at this stage.

 

3. Immature senile cataract: 

  • The lens is greyish white.
  • Clear cortex is still present, so iris shadow is visible
  • Untreated immature cataracts can progress and develop into intumescent cataracts as a result of swelling and congestion of the lens due to degeneration of lens proteins.

 

4. Mature cortical cataract/ Ripe cataract 

  • The opacification is complete
  • The lens is pearly white

 

 

5. Morgagnian hypermature cataract

  • The whole cortex liquefies and the lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid.
  • The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, altering its position with a change in the position of the head.

questions.text: You are performing intrauterine insemination during the ovulatory period in a patient with infertility. When will you expect implantation to occur?
questions.solution:
The fertilized ovum implants by 6–10 days in the uterine cavity.

Implantation involves: 

  •  Apposition: Initial contact of the blastocyst to the uterine wall
  •  Adhesion: Increased physical contact between the blastocyst and uterine epithelium
  •  Invasion: Penetration and invasion of syncytiotrophoblast and cytotrophoblasts into the endometrium

A successful implantation requires receptive endometrium primed with estrogen and progesterone released by the corpus luteum.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a fever and chronic cough is administered 0.1 mL of purified protein derivative intradermally over the forearm. After a few hours, the injection site appears as follows.  Which of the following does this represent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario shows a positive tuberculin test. It is a classical example of type IV or delayed or cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction.

Tuberculin test involves intradermal injection of purified protein derivative (PPD, also called tuberculin), a protein-containing antigen of the tubercle bacillus. In a previously sensitized individual, reddening and induration of the site appear in 8 to 12 hours, reach a peak in 24 to 72 hours, and thereafter slowly subside. 

Morphologically, delayed-type hypersensitivity is characterized by the accumulation of mononuclear cells, mainly CD4+ T cells and macrophages, around venules. The cell-mediated type of hypersensitivity is caused by inflammation resulting from cytokines produced by CD4+ T cells and cell killing by CD8+ T cells.

Related Pearl: Examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity

  • Lepromin test
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Chronic graft rejection
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Type I lepra reaction
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Psoriasis

questions.text: While administering spinal anaesthesia to a patient, which of the following structures would you not be piercing?
questions.solution:
During spinal anaesthesia administration, the posterior longitudinal ligament is not pierced.

The following structures are pierced during spinal anaesthesia, in that order:

  1. Skin
  2. Subcutaneous tissue
  3. Supraspinous ligament
  4. Interspinous ligament
  5. Ligamentum flavum 
  6. Dura mater
  7. Arachnoid

Resistance or first snap is offered by the ligamentum flavum, as this layer is tough and dense.

While, the “click” or “pop” give-away sensation is encountered on piercing the dura, which indicates the needle is in the subarachnoid space. The stylet is then removed from the spinal needle, and CSF should appear at the needle hub.

questions.text: In the metabolism of xenobiotics, all of the following are phase 1 reactions except?
questions.solution:
Acetylation is a phase 2 reaction.

Metabolizing enzymes in hepatic cells:

  • Microsomal enzymes - present in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum
  • Non-microsomal enzymes - present in mitochondria and cytoplasm

Related Pearl: Phases of drug metabolism

Phase I reactions: They attach functional groups to the drugs. This usually leads to the inactivation of the drug. 

Examples:

  • Oxidation
  • Reduction
  • Hydrolysis
  • Cyclisation
  • Deamination

Phase II reactions: They attach conjugates to the drugs. This facilitates drug elimination from the tissue. 

Examples:

  • Glucuronide conjugation
  • Sulfate conjugation
  • Glycine conjugation
  • Glutathione conjugation
  • Acetylation
  • Methylation

All phase II reactions are mainly conducted by the non-microsomal enzymes except glucuronidation.

questions.text: In a patient who is under anaesthesia, which is the most common method used to evaluate intraoperative awareness?
questions.solution:
The bispectral index (BIS) is the most commonly used method, which helps to monitor the depth of anaesthesia and intraoperative awareness.

It processes the EEG and provides an index value between 0 and 100 that indicates the patient’s level of consciousness.

BIS index range: 

  • 100– Awake (Response to normal voice)
  • 65-85- Sedation
  • 40-65- General anaesthesia
  • < 40 - Cortical suppression
  • 0- Flatline EEG (Deep coma)

Recommended range of BIS index values for anaesthesia- 40-60.

questions.text: USG done on a  pregnant woman shows Spalding’s sign. Which of the following is most likely?
questions.solution:
USG showing Spalding’s sign is suggestive of maceration of the fetus. This sign refers to the overlapping of the fetal skull bones caused by the collapse of the fetal brain. 

Maceration is a process of aseptic autolysis occurring after the intrauterine death of the fetus. The prerequisite for the process of maceration to occur is that the dead fetus should be in utero for 3-4 days and should be surrounded by the liquor amnii. If air enters the liquor amnii after the death of the fetus, putrefaction occurs instead of maceration.

Note: Mummification is the term for a dry decomposition of a dead body, or conversion to waxy substances, called adipocere.

Related Pearl: Important Changes in Maceration

  • Earliest sign – reddening of the skin with peeling (12 hours)
  • Skull bones—loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of cranial vault and overlapping which is seen on a radiograph, called Spalding's sign, due to shrinkage of the brain after death; seen within a few days of the death of the fetus.
  • Emits a rancid odor
  • The body is soft and pliable and flattens out when placed on an even surface.
  • Skin—sodden and coppery red/purplish (never greenish as with putrefaction) with blisters, and cuticle peeling.
  • Abdomen - distended
  • Umbilical cord - thick, red smooth, soft.
  • Joints - abnormally mobile or flexible
  • Body cavity presents reddish serum
  • Organs/viscera—soft and oedematous, lose their morphology, but lungs and uterus remain unaffected for long period.

Related Pearl: Radiological features of Intrauterine Death

  • Robert's sign - The presence of a gas shadow within the chambers of the heart or the greater vessels like aorta, in cases of foetal death in utero
  • Spalding sign - Loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of cranial vault and overlapping of skull bones due to shrinkage of brain after death
  • Deuel’s halo sign – Increased pericranial fat
  • Hyperflexion of spine and crowding of ribs

questions.text: Which of the following is not a diagnostic criterion for irritable bowel syndrome?

choices.text: Persistent diarrhoea after a 48 hour fast

questions.solution:
Persistent diarrhoea after a 48-hour fast is not a diagnostic criteria for IBS.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old underwent coronary stent implantation. He was prescribed dual antiplatelet therapy for 6 months in which clopidogrel is one of the components. Which of the following is not true about this drug?

choices.text: The onset of action is slow
It is activated by the hepatic CYP2C19
It has a long duration of action

questions.solution:
Clopidogrel acts by irreversible inhibition of P2Y12 receptors of the platelets.

Options B and C: The onset of action is slow (starts after 4 hours) as it requires metabolic activation by the hepatic CYP2C19 enzyme. Patients with a loss of function mutation of the CYP2C19 allele exhibit reduced platelet inhibition and experience a higher rate of cardiovascular events.

Option D: Due to irreversible inhibition of platelet P2Y12 receptors the duration of action is long and lasts for 5-7 days.

questions.text: A patient with complaints of vaginal discharge was evaluated. On an endocervical biopsy, chlamydia was detected. How will you treat this patient?
questions.solution:
A single dose of 1 g of azithromycin is given and contact tracing is done to treat a patient diagnosed with a chlamydial infection.

Treatment of chlamydial infection:

  • Azithromycin 1 g single dose (or)
  • Doxycycline 100 mg orally BID × 7 days (or)
  • Ofloxacin 200 mg orally BID × 7 days (or)
  • Erythromycin 500 mg orally BID × 7 days

Contact tracing should always be done. The sexual partner should also be treated with the same regimen.

questions.text: You are investigating an outbreak of diarrhea.  You find out that the etiological agent causes stacked-brick formation on hep-2 cells as shown below.  What is the likely organism?
questions.solution:
The stacked-brick pattern of adherence on hep-2 cells is caused by enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC).

Enteroaggregative E. coli has been associated with persistent diarrhea. Intestinal colonization of EAEC is mediated by aggregative adherence fimbriae (AAF). EAST-1 toxin (enteroaggregative heat-stable toxin) is considered to be a major virulence factor for EAEC.

The given image shows the stacked-brick pattern of adherence on microscopy at 600x magnification.

questions.text: According to Factories Act of 1948, a welfare officer has to be employed if the number of employees is:
questions.solution:
A welfare officer has to be employed if the number of employees is > 500 according to the Factories Act of 1948.

According to the Factories Act, safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 employees – Safety Officer
  • > 500 employees – Welfare Officer
  • > 250 employees – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: Antiphospholipid syndrome is associated with all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Thrombocytosis is not associated with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). On the contrary, thrombocytopenia is seen.

APS is an autoantibody-mediated condition that is characterized by arterial thrombosis, venous thrombosis, and recurrent fetal loss. These autoantibodies bind to the phospholipids present on the endothelial cells and activate coagulation and thrombus formation.

Important manifestations of venous thrombosis are:

  • Deep vein thrombosis of legs
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Livedo reticularis
  • Cerebral venous thrombosis

Important manifestations of arterial thrombosis are:

  • Stroke, transient ischemic attacks
  • Retinal artery thrombosis
  • Myocardial ischemia
  • Libman-Sacks endocarditis- due to the vegetations formed by platelet fibrin microthrombi
  • Leg ulcers, gangrene of the digits

Important obstetric manifestations are:

  • Preeclampsia
  • Recurrent fetal loss
  • Premature birth

Important hematological abnormalities are:

  • Thrombocytopenia- occurs due to increased platelet aggregation and thrombus formation 
  • Coombs positive hemolytic anemia- seen when autoantibodies attack red blood cells
  • Thrombotic microangiopathic syndromes- thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with features of bilateral conductive hearing loss, not associated with tinnitus. The following image shows the otoscopic findings of her tympanic membranes. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The otoscopic picture of both the tympanic membranes shows the Schwartze sign. This finding along with the history of bilateral conductive deafness is seen in active otosclerosis.

A reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. 

The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile.

Option A: Rising sun sign is seen in glomus tumor.

Option C: Setting sun sign is an eye sign seen in hydrocephalus.

Option D: Cartwheel appearance is seen in acute suppurative otitis media.

questions.text: A term neonate born by vacuum-assisted delivery developed mild respiratory distress 1 hour after birth. Arterial oxygen saturation remained > 95% without supplemental oxygen. Chest radiography performed 6 hours after birth is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and radiograph showing a spinnaker sign is suggestive of pneumomediastinum.

Spinnaker sign (also called angel wing sign) is a radiographic sign seen in neonates with pneumomediastinum. Pneumomediastinum is the presence of extraluminal gas within the mediastinum. The pressure from the collected gas displaces the two lobes of the thymic tissue upward and laterally from its normal position. This results in large, wedge-shaped opacities on radiograph resembling the spinnaker headsails of a boat.

This should be distinguished from a thymic sail sign which is a normal finding on a neonatal chest x-ray. It represents a physiologically enlarged thymus in a neonate.

Other signs of pneumomediastinum are:

  • V sign of Naclerio - It is due to a V-shaped air collection. One limb of the V is produced by mediastinal air outlining the left lower lateral mediastinal border and the other limb is produced by air between the parietal pleura and medial left hemidiaphragm.
  • Continuous diaphragm sign - Normally the central portion of the diaphragm is not discretely visualised on chest radiographs as it merges with the cardiac silhouette. If the diaphragm can be seen continuously across the midline then it is suggestive of free gas within the mediastinum.

questions.text: What is PACS in medical imaging?
questions.solution:
Picture archiving and communication system (PACS) is a modality of imaging technology that helps in image transmission from the site of acquisition of images, to multiple different sites at different locations.

This is not only economical (film-less department), but is also convenient to access multiple modalities (radiographs, CT, MRI, ultrasound) simultaneously at multiple locations within the hospital or across the globe.

Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine (DICOM) is a standard for handling, storing, printing, and transmitting information in medical imaging. DICOM is used worldwide to store, exchange, and transmit medical images.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old girl with high myopia was referred by the optometrist for further evaluation. She has a history of recurrent allergic conjunctivitis and persistent eye rubbing. An image is given below. Which of the following statements are true about the given condition?
  1. It is usually associated with regular astigmatism
  2. Corneal topography is the primary diagnostic tool
  3. Keratoplasty is the treatment of choice
  4. Vogt's striae and Rizzuti sign are both findings 
  5. The area of protrusion is mostly inferotemporal
questions.solution:
Keratoconus is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder.  It manifests as characteristic cone-like steepening of the cornea associated with irregular stromal thinning, resulting in a cone-like bulge (protrusion) and significant loss of vision.

The pathogenesis is not fully known. Several associations have been identified, which include rigid contact lens wear, chronic eye rubbing, Down's syndrome, atopic disease, Leber's congenital amaurosis, and connective tissue disease.

It is a non-inflammatory disease. With the exception of the significant loss of vision, other classic signs of inflammation are not usually present. The asymmetrical thinning and the highly irregular corneal topography often causes significant myopia and irregular astigmatism. 

Corneal topography is the primary diagnostic tool for KCN detection. 

Whereas keratoplasty, historically has been the mainstay of treatment for keratoconus, it is now generally reserved for eyes that are unable to achieve functional vision with other surgical or non-surgical modalities and is only considered only as a last resort, in very advanced disease. It is the definitive treatment for keratoconus, not the treatment of choice.

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

questions.text: A man was rushed to the casualty after getting stabbed in the back with a knife. On MRI, a complete transection of one side of the spinal cord is suspected. Which of the following is likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
Fine touch lost on the opposite side
Pain and temperature lost on the same side
Only pain lost on the same side

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has Brown-Sequard syndrome. It is characterized by loss of pain and temperature on the opposite side.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome.

The lesion to fasciculus gracilus or fasciculus cuneatus leads to ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion.

The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contra­lateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion.

Damage to the cor­ticospinal tract produces weakness and spasticity in certain muscle groups on the same side of the body.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cystic fibrosis is not true?

choices.text: Abnormality in CFTR gene leads to defective calcium transport.
Mutation in cystic fibrosis transport regulator is seen.
Males have infertility in adult life

questions.solution:
In cystic fibrosis, abnormalities in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene lead to defective chloride channels and not calcium channels. 

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal-recessive disorder of children and adults. Dysfunction of the CFTR, the primary defect, leads to a wide and variable array of presenting manifestations and complications.

The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion.

More than 95% of males are azoospermic because of failure of development of Wolffian duct structures, but the sexual function is generally unimpaired.

questions.text: A 26-year-old batsman was rushed to the ER when he fell unconscious after a cricket ball hit his head. He regained consciousness later but started to deteriorate rapidly. A plain CT of the patient is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of lucid interval in this patient and the CT image are suggestive of extradural hematoma. The above CT scan shows a large extradural hematoma (hyperdense biconvex/lentiform shape) with a mass effect.

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH) is the accumulation of blood between the skull and the dura. It usually results from arterial disruption, especially of the middle meningeal artery. It lies behind the pterion, which is the thinnest part of the skull. 

In EDH, the patient is initially unconscious from the concussive aspect of the head trauma. The patient then awakens and has a “lucid interval,” while the hematoma sub-clinically expands. As the volume of the hematoma grows, intracranial pressure (ICP) increases, and the patient rapidly becomes lethargic and herniates.

Uncal herniation from an EDH classically causes ipsilateral third nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A patient presents with a painless ulcer on his penis. A Wasserman test is done and is reactive. What is the principle of this test?
questions.solution:
Wassermann's reaction is an example of a complement fixation test. It is a non-specific test for the diagnosis of syphilis. 

An antigen combines with its (specific) antibody in the presence of complement, and the antigen-antibody complex adsorbs the complement. This reaction is not visible and requires the use of an indicator (sheep erythrocytes and the specific anti-erythrocyte antibody).

questions.text: A school teacher presents to the OPD with excessive fatigability and double vision. She says that her symptoms are aggravated towards the end of the day. Her colleagues told her that, lately, she has developed a nasal twang in her voice. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Thymoma is present in more than 75% of the patients with this condition
In most of the cases the thymus is hypoplastic
Myoid cells in thymus serve as the source of autoantigens
Thymus is abnormal in 20% of patients with AChR  antibody–positive status

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of myasthenia gravis (MG). Myoid cells in the thymus serve as the source of autoantigens in this condition. 

The muscle-like cells within the thymus called myoid cells, express AChRs on their surface. These cells are known to serve as a source of autoantigen and trigger autoimmune reactions within the thymus gland. This stimulates the production of autoantibodies, thus causing myasthenia gravis.

The thymus is abnormal in ~75% of patients with AChR antibody-positive MG. In these cases, the thymus is hyperplastic. 10% of the patients show symptoms of thymoma.

questions.solution:
Water is arbitrarily assigned a value of zero HU.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is true regarding pathogenicity of Mycobacteria species?

choices.text: M. tuberculosis is more pathogenic than M. bovis to the humans
M. kansasii can cause a disease indistinguishable from tuberculosis
M. africanum infection is acquired from the environmental source
M. marinum is responsible for tubercular lymphadenopathy

questions.solution:
Mycobacterium kansasii can cause a clinical syndrome that strongly resembles tuberculosis, consisting of hemoptysis, chest pain, and cavitary lung disease. M. kansasii is the most pathogenic non-tuberculous mycobacterial species affecting the lung.

Option A: M. tuberculosis is equally pathogenic as M. bovis to humans and guinea pigs. However, M. bovis but not M. tuberculosis is pathogenic to rabbits.

Option C: M. africanum is a member of the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex. It is is spread by an airborne route from affected individuals and not from an environmental source. 

Option D: M. marinum causes swimming pool granuloma/fish tank granuloma/fish fancier’s finger. M. scrofulaceum causes chronic lymphadenitis.

questions.text: Given below is a barium meal study of a child. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given barium meal study is showing string sign and mushroom sign is suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). 

Congenital (infantile) hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is a condition caused by hypertrophy of the circular pyloric muscles of the stomach, leading to gastric outlet obstruction. It typically presents between 2 to 6 weeks of age with progressive, forceful, non-bilious vomiting immediately after feeding. This results in hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to the loss of fluid, hydrogen and chloride ions. 

On examination, a firm, movable, olive-shaped mass is palpable in the epigastrium., often accompanied by visible gastric peristalsis. Ultrasound is the investigation of choice for this condition. 

Given below is the barium meal study showing string sign and mushroom sign: 

Signs seen in CHPS  Description
String sign Passing of a small streak of barium through the pyloric canal
Double/triple track sign Crowding of muscle folds in the pyloric canal
Diamond sign/twining recess A transient triangular tent-like cleft in the mid-portion of the pyloric canal with the apex pointing inferiorly.
Beak sign The mass impression upon the antrum with a streak of barium pointing towards the pyloric channel
Mushroom sign/kirkin sign/umbrella sign Indentation of the base of the duodenal bulb by pylorus
Caterpillar sign Gastric hyperperistaltic waves
Shoulder sign Round indentation caused by hypertrophied pyloric muscle

The ultrasonographic findings include the cervix sign, which represents hypertrophied pylorus that resembles the uterine cervix and the antral nipple sign, representing the redundant pyloric mucosa protruding into the antrum. These findings are as shown below: 

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: Milind, a young child is brought to you for recurrent respiratory symptoms and dysphagia. After ruling out other causes, you suspect a vascular anomaly that could be compressing the esophagus to be causing the symptoms. A CECT is done and the findings are as shown below. Which of the following vascular anomalies is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario suggests a diagnosis of dysphagia lusoria, which is caused most likely by the aberrant right subclavian artery. The given image suggests the presence of the right aberrant subclavian artery.

Dysphagia lusoria is dysphagia produced due to extrinsic compression of the oesophagus by a developmental vascular anomaly, often an aberrant right subclavian artery or right-sided or double aortic arch.

questions.text: The lateral x-ray of an elderly man shows calcification of the laryngeal cartilages. Which of the following is unlikely to be involved?
questions.solution:
Epiglottis is unlikely to be calcified as it is made up of elastic cartilage.

Only hyaline cartilages can undergo ossification (calcifications on x-ray). It occurs between the ages of 25-65y. These calcifications may be confused with foreign bodies of esophagus or larynx on x-rays.

The hyaline laryngeal cartilages are:

  • Thyroid
  • Cricoid
  • Most of arytenoid.

The elastic laryngeal cartilages are:

  • Epiglottis
  • Corniculate
  • Cuneiform
  • Tip of arytenoid.

questions.text: A pregnant woman was diagnosed with red degeneration of fibroid at 26 weeks of gestation. What is the next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Red degeneration of fibroid is managed conservatively with bed rest and analgesics.

It is most common during the second trimester of pregnancy. Red degeneration presents with acute abdominal pain, fever and, vomiting. Investigations reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR. On radiology, the hemorrhagic areas appear hyperechoic within the fibroid.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of conversion disorder?
questions.solution:
Autonomic symptoms are not seen in conversion disorder (functional neurological symptom disorder).

A conversion disorder is an acute and temporary loss or alteration in motor or sensory function triggered by psychosocial stress. Most of the patients have a history of traumatic events in childhood. The symptoms or deficits of conversion disorder are not intentionally produced. There is a time difference seen between the stressors and symptoms. 

The channeling or conversion of the emotional arousal to physical symptoms is primary gain, while the benefits that come out of having the physical symptoms is the secondary gain. For example, it forcing a spouse to stay in an otherwise failing marriage.

La Belle indifference (beautiful indifference) refers to the patient's blissful indifference to what appears to be a significant impairment. 

Related Pearl: Conversion Disorder

Conversion disorder: Also called functional neurological symptom disorder.

Common presenting symptoms:

  • Weakness and/or paralysis
  • Non-epileptic seizures
  • Movement disorders
  • Speech or visual impairment like mutism or blindness
  • Swallowing difficulty
  • Sensory disturbances
  • Cognitive symptoms

Diagnostic criteria:

  • Symptoms of altered neurological function-voluntary motor or sensory
  • Often precipitated by a psychological stressor (the temporal relationship between stressor and symptoms is present)
  • Not feigned or intentionally produced (as in factitious disorder or malingering)
  • Findings incompatible with a recognized neurological condition
  • Symptoms cause significant social or occupational impairment

Other important features:

  • Primary gain - Unconscious relief from stress as the focus of the patient shifts to the symptoms.
  • Secondary gain - Attention gained by the patient (from bystanders) as a result of the symptoms.
  • La-belle indifference - refers to an absence of concern towards one’s problem despite severe disability
  • Astasia abasia - Wildly ataxic, staggering gait accompanied by irregular, jerky truncal movements, thrashing and waving arm movements

Management options:

  • First-line: Education and self-help technique
  • Second-line: Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Physical therapy for motor symptoms

questions.text: Niki, a 9-month-old baby is brought to the OPD for a rash. The mother says the baby had a high fever of 103 F for 3 days for which she was given paracetamol. This morning, the baby had no fever but the mother noticed a rash on the trunk. On oral examination, ulcers at the uvulopalatoglossal junction are present. Which of the following statements is false regarding this disease?

choices.text: It is also called as erythema subitum
It is caused by human herpes virus-6
It is a non-pruritic, morbilliform rash on the trunk

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of roseola infantum. It is also called exanthema subitum, not erythema subitum.

Roseola infantum is also called as sixth disease or exanthema subitum (exanthema=breaking out, subitum=sudden rash). It is caused by a human herpesvirus (HHV) -6A, 6B, and 7.

Clinical features:

  • Prodrome of high-grade fever
  • Non-pruritic, morbilliform rash, which appears as the fever comes down.
  • Leucopenia and relative lymphocytosis
  • Nagayama spots: ulcers at uvulo-palatoglossal junction

Image: Exanthem subitum

questions.text: A 33-year-old male patient was transfused with 2 units of fresh frozen plasma following a road traffic accident. Within 2 hours of the transfusion, he became breathless and his oxygen saturation dropped to 88%. Chest X-ray showed batwing appearance. This condition occurs due to which of the following?

choices.text: Preformed IgM Ab to ABO Ag

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). The presence of antibodies against the Human Leukocyte antigen (Anti-HLA Ab) in the donor blood is implicated in the development of TRALI.

TRALI is defined as an acute lung injury that is temporally related to blood transfusion and causes non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema. It occurs within the first six hours following a transfusion. Screening for HLA antibodies has been introduced to prevent TRALI.

TRALI usually results from the transfusion of donor plasma that contains high-titer anti-HLA class II antibodies that bind to recipient leukocytes. The leukocytes aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability. Testing the donor’s plasma for anti-HLA antibodies can support this diagnosis.

The implicated donors are frequently multiparous women. The transfusion of plasma from male and nulliparous women donors reduces the risk of TRALI.

questions.text: In a shotgun-injury victim, you note rat hole appearance of the entry wound. From what range was it most likely fired?
questions.solution:
A rat-hole appearance of the entry wound of a shotgun can be seen from 30 cm to 5 meters of range. 

Rat-hole wounds:

  • Circular rat-hole wound without peripheral satellite pellet holes - 30cm-1m range.
  • Central rat-hole wound with peripheral satellite pellet holes - 1m-5m range.

The image given below shows characteristics of shotgun wounds at various ranges.

  • Muzzle imprint
  • No soot soiling, tattooing or singeing.

  • Muzzle imprint
  • No soot soiling, tattooing or singeing.

<30cm

  • Tattooing - Punctate skin lesions from powder particles.

questions.text: Which of the following statements most appropriately describes the vasomotor reversal of Dale?

choices.text: Stimulation of alpha 1 followed by stimulation of beta 2
Blockade of alpha 1 followed by stimulation of beta 2
Stimulation of alpha 1 followed by blockade of beta 2
Stimulation of beta 1 followed by blockade of beta 2

questions.solution:
Vasomotor reversal of Dale is a blockade of alpha (α1) followed by stimulation of beta (β2) receptors.

Normally, a high dose of epinephrine injected produces an α1-mediated rise in BP followed by a β2-mediated fall in BP.

Administration of epinephrine after administration of α-blockers produces only a fall in BP. This is because the α-mediated response is abolished and hence, only the β-mediated response is seen, resulting in a fall in BP. This phenomenon is called the vasomotor reversal of Dale. This was first demonstrated by Sir H.H.Dale.

questions.text: Which of the following stains is not used in the detection of calcium in tissues?
questions.solution:
The Congo red stain is used for staining amyloid bodies, not calcium.

The following staining techniques are used for calcium:

  • Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) -
    • Calcium forms a blue-black lake with hematoxylin 
  • Azan stain -
    • Used to distinguish osteoid from the mineralized bone
  • Alizarin red S stain -
    • Forms an orange-red lake with calcium
    • Works best with small amounts of calcium
    • An example is Michaelis–Gutmann (MG) bodies, seen in malakoplakia
  • Von Kossa method - 
    • Useful for tissues containing large amounts of phosphates and carbonates, such as bone
    • Silver ions react with phosphate in the presence of acidic material
    • Silver phosphate gets degraded to silver in presence of light, giving black color
    • MG bodies also stain with von kossa stain.

The image given below demonstrates MG bodies which are seen in malakoplakia using the Von Kossa stain.

questions.text:
Which of the following coagulation factors are increased in pregnancy?
  1. II
  2. VII
  3. IX
  4. XI

questions.solution:
All clotting factors increase in pregnancy except factors XI and XIII.

Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state with physiological changes such as:

  • The viscosity of blood decreases due to hemodilution
  • Clotting time and bleeding time is unaffected

The most common cause of decreased platelet count in pregnancy is benign gestational thrombocytopenia. This is due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption and the women are generally asymptomatic.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman complains of recurrent episodes of constipation and crampy abdominal pain for the last 4 months. The pain is relieved on defecation. After investigations, a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome with constipation is considered. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe?
questions.solution:
The drug used in irritable bowel syndrome with constipation is lubiprostone.

It is approved for chronic idiopathic constipation and constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (in female patients >18 years). It acts by stimulating Cl-channels in the intestine and increasing fluid secretion in the gut. This decreases the transit time.

Eluxadoline is an FDA-approved opioid drug for the treatment of diarrhea-predominant IBS in adults.

questions.text: Which of the following steps of disaster management is in correct order?
questions.solution:
The correct order is Disaster impact – Response – Rehabilitation – Mitigation.

Disaster management includes three aspects:

1. Disaster impact and response: It involves immediate management of mass casualties as follows:

  • Search, rescue, and first-aid
  • Field care
  • Triage
  • Tagging
  • Identification of dead

2. Rehabilitation or recovery: It involves the restoration of the pre-disaster conditions by taking steps such as:

  • Water supply
  • Basic sanitation and personal hygiene
  • Food safety
  • Vector control

3. Mitigation: Measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing disaster or to reduce the effects of the disaster. This also includes preparedness for any impending disasters or in disaster-prone areas.

questions.text: While examining a patient with hair loss, you notice several thin, broken hairs that are thinner towards the scalp and easily pulled out. What is the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has alopecia areata. The characteristic finding described in this vignette is called exclamation mark hair. 

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes non-scarring patches of hair loss. It is a T-cell mediated inflammatory disease that occurs in genetically predisposed patients. 

The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia. Exclamation mark hair refers to short extractable broken hairs which are thinner towards the base, as shown in the image below.

questions.text: Which of the following findings are you unlikely to see in a patient with achondroplasia?
questions.solution:
Squaring of the iliac blades and not the acetabula give a tombstone appearance in achondroplasia.

Other radiological findings seen in achondroplasia include:

  • Large skull with -
    • Prominent forehead
    • Depressed nasal bridge
    • Small foramen magnum that is funnel-shaped
  • The epiphyses have V-shaped distal ends with deep intercondylar notches—the ‘chevron’ sign
  • Bullet nose vertebrae with posterior scalloping
  • Trident hand (as shown below)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of the following pathological change seen in the spleen?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a pale, wedge-shaped area of infarction in the spleen.

An infarct is a region of ischaemic necrosis resulting from the obstruction of blood flow, typically due to occlusion of the arterial supply or venous drainage. The most common cause of solid organ infarts is thromboembolism.

The pattern of ischemic necrosis seen in solid organ infarction is coagulative necrosis. However, CNS infarctions are an exception. They cause liquefactive necrosis.

questions.text: What is the procedure of choice in a patient with chronic anal fissure?
questions.solution:
Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice for chronic anal fissures.

Surgical therapy has traditionally been recommended for chronic anal fissures that have failed medical therapy. The aim of this procedure is to decrease the spasms of the internal sphincter by dividing a portion of the muscle. Approximately 30% of the muscle sphincter fibers are divided laterally using an open or closed technique.

The initial treatment of anal fissures includes:

  1. Frequent sitz baths
  2. Analgesics
  3. Stool softeners
  4. High-fiber diet

If conservative management with dietary changes and laxatives fail, other options including topical analgesics such as 2% lidocaine jelly, topical nifedipine, topical nitroglycerin, or a combination of topical nifedipine and lidocaine can be attempted.

Option A: Miligan-Morgan procedure is an open hemorrhoidectomy

Option C: Transanal resection is used to remove early-stage rectal cancers in the lower rectum

Option D: Altermeier's procedure is used for rectal prolapse

questions.text: Maple syrup urine disease type I  is due to a defect in _____.
questions.solution:
Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) type I is due to impaired alpha-Ketoacid decarboxylase component of BCKAD (branched chain alpha keto acid dehydrogenase) complex, leading to defective decarboxylation reaction and the formation of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine) and their toxic byproducts (keto-acids) in blood and urine.

A peculiar odor (burnt sugar) is found in urine, sweat, and cerumen.

Note: Amino-acids and disorders of their metabolism are invariably being asked in NEET as well as in AIIMS examinations.

Related Pearl: Maple syrup urine disease(MSUD)

questions.text: Where are granules of Eleidin seen?
questions.solution:
Granules of Eleidin are clear intracellular proteins present in the stratum lucidum of the thick skin of palms and soles.

The cytoplasm of this layer is packed with keratin filaments and Eleidin granules giving it a translucent appearance. It is also called the clear cell layer.

questions.text: While assessing the Apgar score of the newborns, you would assess and score all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Respiratory effort, not rate is a component of Apgar score.

The Apgar score is an objective method of evaluating the newborn's condition using the 5 parameters explained below. It is performed at 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth.

  • Color (A, appearance)
  • Heart rate (P, pulse)
  • Response to a catheter in nostril (G, grimace)
  • Muscle tone (A, activity)
  • Respiratory effort (R)

Apgar score is not used to guide resuscitation, and resuscitation must be initiated before the 1-minute score. The change of score at sequential time points following birth reflects how well the baby is responding to resuscitative efforts.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: Acantholysis is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Acantholysis is not seen in bullous pemphigoid as it is associated with subepidermal blistering.

Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, resulting in the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes.

Seen in:

  • Varicella-zoster infections (chickenpox, shingles)

questions.text: Which of the following multienzyme complexes catalyzing decarboxylation reactions does not require thiamine as a coenzyme?
questions.solution:
Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) does not serve as the coenzyme for isocitrate dehydrogenase. 

Isocitrate dehydrogenase, an enzyme of the citric acid cycle, uses Mg2+ or Mn2+ ions as a coenzyme. 

Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), from vitamin B1, serves as the coenzyme for three multienzyme complexes that catalyze oxidative decarboxylation reactions:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase - carbohydrate metabolism
  • α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase - citric acid cycle
  • Branched-chain keto-acid dehydrogenase - metabolism of leucine, isoleucine, valine

Most of these enzymes are involved in carbohydrate metabolism, so thiamine is required in excess during a high carbohydrate diet. TPP also serves as the cofactor for transketolase in the HMP shunt.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the given image?

choices.text: It is associated with facial angiofibroma
They are diagnostic of a neurocutaneous syndrome

questions.solution:
The given image shows discrete tan-colored nodules over the iris called Lisch nodules (pigmented melanocytic hamartomas). They are seen in neurofibromatosis-1 (NF-1). Facial angiofibroma (adenoma sebaceum) is a feature of tuberous sclerosis (TS) and not neurofibromatosis.

The image below shows facial angiofibroma seen in tuberous sclerosis (Bourneville disease).

Lisch nodules are specifically associated with NF-1 and are usually multiple and bilateral. They are best visualized with a slit lamp examination and don’t cause any visual disturbances.

Other important ocular manifestations in NF-1 include eyelid plexiform neurofibroma, which causes S-shaped deformity of the upper lid, with a 'bag of worms' like texture, optic nerve glioma, and spheno-orbital encephalocele due to dysplasia of greater wing of the sphenoid.

NF-1 (von Recklinghausen's disease) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a loss-of-function mutation of the NF-1 gene located on chromosome 17q11.2. NF-1 produces neurofibromin, which acts as a tumor suppressor and a negative regulator of RAS-MAP kinase signaling.

Clinical features of NF-1 include café-au-lait macules, axillary freckling, Lisch nodules,  neurofibromas, and optic gliomas. 
NF-1 is more common than NF2 and typically diagnosed in childhood. NF-2 is rarer but often presents with bilateral acoustic neuroma, juvenile cataract and schwannoma.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the bony Bankart lesion?

choices.text: Avulsion fracture of the glenoid rim
Stripping of the antero-inferior glenoid labrum
Rupture of inferior glenohumeral ligament complex

questions.solution:
The bony bankart lesion is a small, avulsion fracture of the glenoid rim.

During an anterior shoulder dislocation, the head of the humerus can tear the anteroinferior part of the glenoid labrum. This is known as Bankart lesion. In some cases, a small fragment of bone from the glenoid rim can also get avulsed. This is known as a bony Bankart lesion.

Avulsion of posterior capsular periosteum is seen in reverse Bankart lesion.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with recent onset facial asymmetry and a lump over the roof of the mouth for the past 1 year. On examination, a solitary erythematous swelling with diffuse borders is seen over the left hard palate. Biopsy of the lesion reveals a swiss cheese pattern. Which of the following conditions is she likely to have?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and biopsy finding is suggestive of adenoid cystic carcinoma.  Facial asymmetry points to the perineural invasion of the tumor into the facial nerve, which is characteristic of adenoid cystic carcinoma.

It is the second most common malignant tumor of the parotid gland. It is a slow-growing tumor most commonly involving the parotid and submandibular glands. Histology shows a swiss cheese pattern. The tubular type has the best prognosis, while the solid type has the worst. 

It has a deceptively benign histologic appearance characterized by indolent, locally invasive growth with a high propensity for local recurrence and distant metastasis. The most common site of distant metastasis is the lung. Treatment involves removal of the gross tumor, with radiation therapy for the microscopic disease.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A man was seen for an asymptomatic spotty eruption, of approximately 2 weeks duration, that are localized predominantly to the anterior chest, abdomen, and neck regions. Physical examination revealed several scattered light blue-red, oval to round spots. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Maculae cerulae are blue-red/grey-colored macules on the skin characteristically seen in pediculosis pubis which is caused due to the infestation by pubic louse (Pthirus pubis/crab louse). They mark the hemosiderin-stained purpuric spots where lice have fed.

questions.text: Where are Peg cells seen?
questions.solution:
Peg cells are seen in the fallopian tubes.

A peg cell is a non-ciliated epithelial cell within the fallopian tube. These cells are also known as intercalated or intercalary cells whose function is not yet known.

questions.text: A child was brought to you with recurrent episodes of colicky abdominal pain. USG revealed left-sided hydronephrosis. On the third follow-up day, a decrease in abdominal pain was noted after he passed a large amount of urine. Repeat USG showed a significant decrease in the size of the left kidney. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of hydronephrosis with renal pain relieved after the passage of a large amount of urine is suggestive of Dietl's crisis.

It is defined as intermittent ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction causing episodic abdominal pain and nausea, most often due to an aberrant accessory renal artery or vein.

In an acute phase of ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction, loin swelling occurs along with renal pain due to the retention of urine in the kidney. When the obstruction is relieved, the patient passes a large amount of urine, the swelling is reduced and the pain disappears. This is termed Dietl's crisis.

In the majority of cases, pyeloplasty results in the complete resolution of symptoms.

questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV positive man presents with an acute onset high-grade fever with chills and shortness of breath. On evaluation, he's diagnosed to have a necrotising mediastinitis secondary to rupture of a retropharyngeal abscess. What is the likely route of spread of infection to the mediastinum?

choices.text: Between  buccopharyngeal fascia and alar fascia.
Between alar fascia and prevertebral fascia
Between the capsule of tonsil and superior constrictor muscle

questions.solution:
The likely route of spread of infection is between the alar fascia anteriorly and the prevertebral fascia posteriorly. It is also called the danger space or alar space.

It lies just posterior to the retropharyngeal space. It extends from the skull base to the diaphragm. Infections from this space can spread to the mediastinum, and hence it is named the danger space.

questions.text: Which among the following is a branch from the upper trunk of brachial plexus?

questions.text: In a patient with a positive Casoni's skin test,  which of the following infections will you suspect?
questions.solution:
Casoni’s skin test is done in patients with hydatid disease.

It is an immediate hypersensitivity reaction (type I). Sterile hydatid fluid is injected (0.2 mL) intradermally in one arm and an equal volume of saline as control is injected in the other arm. In a positive reaction, a large wheal appears within half an hour. A secondary reaction consisting of edema and induration appears after 8 hours. 

This test is abandoned now due to non-specificity and has been supplemented by serological tests.

Related Pearl: Skin tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Skin tests are performed by injecting parasitic antigen intradermally and observing the reaction. In immediate hypersensitivity reaction, wheal and flare response is seen within 30 minutes of injection, whereas in delayed type of hypersensitivity, erythema and induration are seen after 48 hours of injection.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is on carbamazepine therapy. Which of the following is expected to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Carbamazepine is expected to cause hyponatremia in this patient.

Carbamazepine potentiates the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). It can result in water retention with decreased osmolarity and hyponatremia, especially in elderly patients with cardiac disease.

questions.text: You are asked to conduct an autopsy of a person who was found dead at his home. You notice the given findings on the body. Which test can be used to differentiate this from antemortem bruising?
questions.solution:
The given image shows postmortem hypostasis. The classic test used to differentiate a bruise from hypostasis is the incision test. 

The suspected area is incised to see if the underlying blood is intravascular (hypostasis) or infiltrating the tissues outside the vessels (contusion).

Option A: Gettler's chloride test is used to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning. It is not widely used now. 

Option C: In the precipitin test, a specific antiserum is made to react with the seminal fluid, blood, or saliva. A positive test will confirm human origin.

Option D: Breslau's second life test is done to determine whether a child was born alive or not.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought with gradually progressive pain below his left knee over the past 6 months. An X-ray reveals the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a lytic lesion with a dense sclerotic rim and minimal periosteal reaction. This is suggestive of Brodie's abscess.

Brodie’s abscess is a subacute variant of osteomyelitis with a milder presentation. It occurs when organisms of low virulence infect an immunocompetent host. The abscess is walled off by the thickening of the surrounding bone trabeculae. It most commonly involves the metaphysis of the proximal tibia and distal femur.

Patients present with intermittent pain and tenderness in the affected area. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy, and it is managed by antibiotics and curettage. The following x-ray and MRI images show Brodie's abscess of the radius in a patient.

Option B: Sclerosing osteomyelitis of Garre appears as a markedly sclerotic lesion with extensive periosteal reaction.

Option C: Chronic osteomyelitis is diagnosed by the presence of sequestrum, involucrum, and cloacae. 

Option D: Osteoclastoma commonly occurs between 20-40 years of age and is unlikely in children. On a radiograph, it appears as a lytic lesion with a thin sclerotic rim and minimal periosteal reaction with a soap bubble appearance.

  • Injury leads to torrential haemorrhage which is difficult to control.

questions.text: While browsing through the news channels, Geeta came across a panel discussion on public health diseases celebrating the elimination of a peculiar condition of the eye. It was known as the most important cause of corneal blindness in India and shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given sago-grain appearance of the conjunctiva is seen in trachoma. It was the most important cause of corneal blindness in India affecting young children.

On December 08, 2017, Shri J P Nadda, Union Minister of Health and Family Welfare at that time, released the National Trachoma Survey Report and declared that India is now free from 'infective trachoma'.

questions.text: What is included in Klein-Levin syndrome?
questions.solution:
Klein-Levin syndrome is one of the primary hypersomnias.

It is characterized by the following:

  • Hypersomnia - always present, occurring recurrently for long periods of time (18-hour to 20-hour sleep periods)
  • Hyperphagia
  • Hypersexuality
  • Disinhibition (aggression)

Studies show diffuse brain hypoperfusion, mostly focused on the thalamic and frontotemporal areas on SPECT scan in patients with Klein-Levin syndrome during the symptomatic period.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the dermatologist by her parents. She has many freckles on her face and limbs as shown below. She is also unusually sensitive to sunlight. Early changes of squamous cell carcinomas are also noted on her face. Which of the following processes is most like to be defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Photosensitivity, freckling and skin cancer on the face in a child aare suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum. It is an example of defective DNA nucleotide excision repair. 

In xeroderma pigmentosum, there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure. It is an autosomal recessive disease characterized by exaggerated sunburns and pigmentary changes on exposure to UV radiations. There is increased risk of developing non-melanoma and melanoma skin cancers, and neurodegeneration. They are also more prone to developing smoking-induced lung cancers. 

Diagnosis is mainly clinical and it can be confirmed definitively by cellular tests for defective DNA repair. Management includes sun avoidance and regular follow-up to assess and treat any skin cancers. There is no cure for xeroderma pigmentosum.

questions.text: The Topographic Theory of Mind was described by_____
questions.solution:
Sigmund Freud described the topographic theory of mind in the year 1900 and has written a book named the interpretation of dreams.

According to the topographic theory of mind, the mind is divided into 3 levels:

  • Unconscious: Contents and thought processes are hidden from conscious awareness through the force of censorship or repression, and it is closely related to instinctual drives.
  • Preconscious: composed of those mental events, processes, and contents that can be brought into conscious awareness by the act of focusing attention. Although most persons are not consciously aware of the appearance of their first-grade teacher, they ordinarily can bring this image to mind by deliberately focusing attention on the memory.
  • Conscious: part of the mind in which perceptions coming from the outside world or from within the body or mind are brought into awareness.

  • Structural theory of mind- id, ego, superego
  • Cocaine in psychiatry

Other protozoan parasites found in the human small intestine do not occur in the lumen but are present in the epithelial cells lining the small intestine. These include:

questions.text: A 12-year-old is brought to the emergency with features of intestinal obstruction. An ultrasound reveals a target sign, suggesting intussusception. On closer examination, her palm and oral mucosa are spotted with multiple 1-2 mm blue-gray macules. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient most likely has Peutz–Jeghers syndrome.

It is characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract (more commonly small intestine) and hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits. In the given clinical scenario, the patient has had an intestinal intussusception. The numerous polyps in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome often serve as a lead point.

Option A: Turcot syndrome constitutes colorectal polyps and brain tumors (including cerebellar medulloblastoma and glioblastomas)

Option B: Lynch syndrome is also called hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC). It is due to defective mismatch repair (MMR) of DNA.

Option D: Cowden syndrome is characterized by polyps of the stomach or colon, macrocephaly and benign tumors of thyroid, breast, and uterus.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text: Which is the most sensitive index of recent transmission of malaria?
questions.solution:
The infant parasite rate is regarded as the most sensitive index for recent transmission of malaria in a locality.

It is defined as the % of infants showing malarial parasites in their blood films. The transmission of malaria is considered absent if the infant parasite rate is zero for 3 consecutive years in a locality (even though the Anopheline vectors responsible for the previous transmission may remain).

questions.text: The USG scan of a multiparous woman at 30 weeks of gestation showed the presence of an accessory placental lobe. Which complication will you not anticipate in her?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of the presence of an accessory placental lobe is suggestive of placenta succenturiata. Preterm delivery is not a complication seen in this condition. 

Complications of placenta succenturiata include:

  • Retained placenta 
  • Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)
  • Subinvolution of uterus
  • Sepsis
  • Placental polyp formation
  • Vasa previa - vessels overlying the accessory lobes can cross the cervix. Their rupture can lead to hemorrhage from the fetus

Note: Preterm delivery is a complication associated with circumvallate placenta.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions have defective phagolysosome formation?
questions.solution:
Defective phagolysosome formation is seen in patients with Chediak–Higashi syndrome (CHS). It is a rare autosomal recessive defect.

There is an abnormal fusion of azurophilic lysosomes of neutrophils and cytoplasmic granules of monocytes and lymphocytes, which leads to the presence of giant lysosomal granules. Hence, there is abnormal post-phagocytic phagolysosomal fusion, degranulation, and impaired microbicidal activity. There is rapid neutrophil turnover leading to low counts. 

Clinical features include:

  • Recurrent infections -
    • Commonly affect the skin, upper and lower respiratory tract
    • Common organisms - Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, Group A Streptococcus, Gram-negative enteric (Klebsiella, Proteus, Shigella, Pseudomonas)
  • Accelerated phase in some patients - 
    • Hemophagocytic syndrome and aggressive lymphoma
    • These patients require bone marrow transplantation
  • Albinism with neurological defects

questions.text: What is the type of strangulation shown in this image called?
questions.solution:
The image shows the tightening of a noose around the neck by twisting a rod within the ligature. This is called garrotting. 

This is a mode of ligature strangulation that may be seen in homicide.

This was a form of judicial execution once employed in Spain. The rod-like object used to tighten the ligature is called a Spanish windlass - this may be a ruler, stick, or screwdriver. The method was also used by Thagi’s in the past in India, to kill the travelers and rob their belongings in lonely places.

questions.text: The phenomenon in which the rapidly growing cells upregulate glucose and glutamine uptake and decrease their production of ATP per glucose molecule is called ________
questions.solution:
Warburg effect

  • Pure oxidative phosphorylation produces abundant adenosine triphosphate ATP, but also “burns” glucose to CO2 and H2O, leaving no carbon moieties suitable for use as building blocks for lipids or proteins.
  • For this reason, rapidly growing cells (both benign and malignant) upregulate glucose and glutamine uptake and decrease their production of ATP per glucose molecule, a phenomenon called the Warburg effect.

Other options:

  • Option a: Crabtree effect: It is a phenomenon whereby yeast species, such as Saccharomyces cerevisiae, produce ethanol (alcohol) in aerobic conditions and high external glucose concentrations, rather than producing biomass via the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle.
  • Option c: Pasteur effect: It refers to the effect first discovered by Louis Pasteur, wherein aerating yeasted broth causes an increase in yeast cell growth, while conversely decreasing the fermentation rate. The effect occurs due to the difference in the efficiency of energy production by the anaerobic and aerobic pathways (citric acid cycle).
  • Option d: Haldane effect: It is a property of hemoglobin, where oxygenation of blood in the lungs displaces carbon dioxide from hemoglobin, thereby increasing the removal of carbon dioxide.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was diagnosed with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and was started on levothyroxine 2 weeks ago. She now presents to your clinic with abdominal pain and dizziness. The left and right images below show her current appearance and her appearance last month, respectively. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image showing skin hyperpigmentation in a patient with severe dizziness and a history of autoimmune thyroiditis points to a diagnosis of Addison’s disease. Hyperglycemia is not a feature of this condition. Hypocortisolism leads to hypoglycemia in these patients.

Addison’s disease is primary adrenal insufficiency characterized by the disruption of glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and androgen secretion. Primary adrenal insufficiency is most commonly caused by autoimmune adrenalitis and coincident autoimmune disease occurring in these patients most frequently includes thyroid autoimmune disease, vitiligo, and premature ovarian failure.

questions.solution:
Buprenorphine is a partial agonist at the mu receptor with a lower intrinsic activity compared to morphine and hence does not produce withdrawal symptoms in patients with morphine dependence.

Buprenorphine is a synthetic thebaine congener and also acts as an antagonist at kappa receptor. 

It is more potent than morphine at mu receptor but with lower intrinsic activity and ceiling effect. Due to lower intrinsic activity, it has no withdrawal symptoms and can be used in the treatment of morphine dependence.

questions.text: Muscle cannot release glucose from glycogen because of the deficiency of which of the following  enzymes?
questions.solution:
Muscles cannot release glucose into the blood due to the absence of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase.

Glucose-6-phosphatase is present in the lumen of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes. Hence, hepatocytes can convert glucose-6-phosphate into glucose and release glycogen-derived glucose into the blood in order to maintain blood glucose levels stable, until gluconeogenesis kicks in. 

However, myocytes lack the enzyme glucose 6-phosphatase. As a result, glucose-6-phosphate cannot be dephosphorylated and released into the blood. Muscle glycogen provides a readily available source of glucose-1-phosphate for glycolysis within the muscle itself.

Defects in the enzyme or glucose-6-phosphate transporter (GLUT 7) can cause type I glycogen storage disease.

questions.text: A 66-year-old chronic smoker presents with progressive shortness of breath and chronic cough. On examination, he has a barrel chest and has pursed-lip breathing. Hyperresonance and inspiratory wheezes are heard. Pulmonary functions are likely to reveal all of the following, except:

choices.text: Increased diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide

questions.solution:
The given clinical diagnosis is suggestive of COPD and the underlying pathological change is likely to be emphysema. It is associated with a decreased diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO).

Emphysema is defined pathologically as the abnormal and permanent dilation of airways distal to the terminal bronchiole, along with the destruction of their walls. This leads to hyperinflation due to air trapping and impaired diffusion of gases.

Pulmonary function tests in COPD:

  • TLC: Normal or increased
  • FEV1: Decreased (<80% predicted)
  • FVC: Decreased
  • FEV1/FVC: Decreased
  • DLCO: Decreased

Diseases associated with lowered DLCO:

  • Emphysema
  • Interstitial Lung disease
  • Primary pulmonary hypertension

Note - Bronchial asthma is associated with an increased DLCO.

questions.text: The mechanism of action of theophylline in bronchial asthma is _____
questions.solution:
Theophylline is a non-selective PDE inhibitor. It is a methylxanthane. Its other actions include: 

  • Adenosine receptor antagonism
  • Increased IL-10 release
  • Decrease in gene transcription of pro-inflammatory cytokines

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presented with fatigue and weight loss. On examination, pallor and splenomegaly were noted. Peripheral blood smear examination findings are shown in the image. Which of the following BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitors is not a first-line agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the peripheral smear findings (increased WBCs with myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band forms), is suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). Bosutinib is approved for use in this condition only for resistant and/or intolerant cases and not in newly diagnosed cases.

Agents that can be used as first-line for CML are:

  • Imatinib
  • Dasatinib
  • Nilotinib 

Dasatinib and nilotinib can be used in newly diagnosed cases of CML, that are found to be imatinib-resistant.

questions.text: A known IV drug abuser is referred to medicine OPD from the de-addiction wing due to prolonged fever and new-onset seizures. His fever has been present for 2 weeks and did not come down with antibiotics. An early diastolic murmur is heard on auscultation. Multiple painless skin lesions are present on the hands. What are these lesions?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of infective endocarditis. The skin lesions shown in the image are Janeway lesions. They are non-tender, erythematous, or hemorrhagic macular or nodular lesions, which are present on the palms or soles.

Another skin finding that can be found in patients with infective endocarditis is Osler's nodes. In contrast to Janeway lesions, these are small, tender, red papules which are present on the distal finger and toe pads.

Osler nodes & Janeway lesions share similar pathogenesis, arises from micro-emboli embedding in different anatomical sites. Pain from Osler nodes is associated with emboli lodging in the glomus apparatus of the dermis. Histologically, both lesions show septic micro-emboli with dermal micro-abscess formation.

questions.text: The forearm of a patient admitted to the psychiatric ward is shown in the image. Which of the following is true about the healed injury?
questions.solution:

Hypertrophic scars rise above the skin level but stay within the confines of the original wound and often regress over time. They have no racial or genetic predilection.

questions.text: You witness a 40-year-old man suddenly collapse near the ER. He is unresponsive and you start chest compressions as his pulse is also not recordable. For maximum effectiveness, what should be the depth of your compressions?
questions.solution:
High-quality cardiopulmonary resuscitation involves adequate chest compressions to a depth of at least 5 cm in adults.

If a feedback device is used, then the compression depth can be increased to 6 cm.

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio
