  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

questions.text: What is the most common mutation identified in patients with autosomal dominant hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.solution:
Mutations of the gene coding for ankyrin are the most common cause of autosomal dominant hereditary spherocytosis.

The following mutations have been identified in hereditary spherocytosis:

Autosomal dominant (more common):

  • Ankyrin - most common
  • Band 3
  • β-Spectrin

Autosomal recessive:

  • α-Spectrin
  • Band 4.2

Missense mutations of band 3 protein result in stomatocytosis. Stomatocytes are RBCs with a mouth-shaped area of central pallor, as shown below. RBCs acquire the shape of a uniconcave cup due to decreased cell volume or decreased membrane surface area.

Some mutations of the band 3 gene are clinically asymptomatic but protective against Plasmodium falciparum.

questions.text: The structure (Red Arrow) shown in the image develops from _______
questions.solution:
The arrow depicts the neurohypophysis which develops from the diencephalon.

The pituitary has two major parts, the neurohypophysis and adenohypophysis, which differ in their origin, structure and function.

The neurohypophysis is a diencephalic downgrowth connected with the hypothalamus.

The adenohypophysis is an ectodermal derivative of the stomatodeum.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was undergoing cholangiography. However, during the procedure, there was difficulty in inserting the catheter through the cystic duct. Which of the following features of the cystic duct is likely to interfere with the passage of the catheter?
questions.solution:
Spiral valves of Heister are the mucosal folds present in the cystic duct. In most cases, they are responsible for causing difficulty in the passage of catheter through the cystic duct.

The mucosa of the cystic duct forms 2–10 crescentic folds which are spirally arranged to form the spiral valve of Heister, also called spiral folds. These are continuous with those in the neck of the gallbladder. The function of these spiral folds is unknown but they may help to preserve the patency of this narrow, tortuous duct.

The cystic duct drains the gallbladder into the common hepatic duct. It unites with the common hepatic duct to form the common bile duct.

Note: Tortuous course of the right hepatic artery, also known as Moynihan's hump or caterpillar hump, is a rare but important anomaly to be recognized to prevent intraoperative vascular and biliary injuries during surgical procedures involving the liver and biliary apparatus.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest cranial nerve to be involved in acoustic neuroma?
questions.solution:
The 8th cranial nerve is the earliest to be involved in acoustic neuroma.

Cochleovestibular symptoms are the earliest symptoms when the tumor is still intracanalicular and are caused by pressure on cochlear or vestibular nerve fibers or on the internal auditory artery.

Once the tumor erodes the canal, it presents in the cerebellopontine angle and can expand to involve other nearby cranial nerves such as the 5th and 7th cranial nerves.

Note: Acoustic neuroma arises from the 8th cranial nerve. Hence, it is the first nerve involved. However, if the 8th cranial nerve is not given as an option, then the answer would be the 5th cranial nerve.

questions.text: A person presents to the emergency department with suspected poisoning due to ingestion of arsenic-containing pesticides 6 hours ago. Which of the following would you not expect to find?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is indicative of acute arsenic poisoning. Mees lines are unlikely to be found in a patient with arsenic ingestion 6 hours ago. It is seen in chronic poisoning. 

Features of acute arsenic poisoning:

  • Severe watery diarrhea (like cholera)
  • QTc prolongation and cardiac arrhythmias
  • Acute encephalopathy
  • Renal injury with acute tubular necrosis
  • Garlic odor of breath and stools

Mees lines are horizontal 1 to 2 mm white lines on the nails, also called transverse leukonychia. They occur due to a disturbance in the nail matrix keratinization. It may be seen 4 to 6 weeks after acute arsenic ingestion. These can also be seen in thallium poisoning.

The image given below shows Mees lines.

questions.text: A 33-week-pregnant lady with pre-eclampsia presents with features suggestive of HELLP syndrome. Which of the following is false about her condition?

choices.text: Corticosteroids aid in increasing platelet count
It is characterised by microangiopathic hemolysis
MgSO4 can be used in the management of HELLP syndrome
Termination of pregnancy is the definitive management

questions.solution:
Corticosteroid treatment for thrombocytopenia is not recommended in patients with HELLP syndrome.

HELLP syndrome is a serious complication in pregnancy characterized by HEmolysis, ELevated liver enzymes, and Low Platelet count. It occurs in 0.5-0.9% of all pregnancies and in 10–20% of patients with severe preeclampsia.  

Management of HELLP syndrome is supportive, including:
- Antiseizure prophylaxis with MgSO4
- Platelet tansfusion if platelet count <50,000/mm3 , FFP transfusion
- Plasmapheresis
- Immediate termination of pregnancy in the interest of the mother.

 The most common cause of maternal death in HELLP syndrome is abruptio placenta and DIC.

questions.text: Based on your observation of the foot of the patient shown below, what is the most likely diagnosis and its inheritance pattern?
questions.solution:
The given image shows periungual fibroma seen in tuberous sclerosis. Periungual fibromas are benign tumors that are composed of connective tissue and typically appear in the second decade of life or later.

Tuberous sclerosis is an inherited neurocutaneous disorder. It is inherited in autosomal dominant pattern.

The clinical features include:

  • Ash-leaf macules - hypopigmented macules -
  • Facial angiofibroma
  • Shagreen patches mostly over the lower back
  • Periungual fibromas

The image below shows an ash leaf macule.

The image below shows a Shagreen patch.

questions.text: Within which part of the gastric gland are the chief cells located?
questions.solution:
Chief cells are located mostly in the basal part of the gastric glands. 

Gastric glands are simple or branched tubular glands that lies perpendicular to the gastric mucosa. They can be identified to have 3 main sections:

  1. Basal part (deep part)
  2. Neck
  3. Isthmus (connects to gastric pit) - Gastric glands open into the gastric pits. 

Types of cells in the gastric glands 

Chief cells (also called peptic or zymogen cells)

  • Mostly found in the basal or deep portion of the gastric glands
  • Cells are cuboidal or low columnar shaped
  • The cytoplasm is basophilic and contains prominent secretory granules
  • Secrete pepsinogen (precursor of pepsin) and lipase

Oxyntic cells (or parietal cells)

  • Found in the upper part of the gland 
  • Cells are large, ovoid or polyhedral
  • Stain strongly with eosin
  • Produce hydrochloric acid (HCl) and intrinsic factor

Mucous neck cells:

  • Prominently found at the neck part of the gastric glands
  • They secrete mucus

Neuroendocrine cells:

  • Situated mostly in the basal or deeper parts of the glands, along with the chief cells. T
  • Cells are pleomorphic-shaped and display irregular nuclei surrounded by granular cytoplasm
  • Synthesize many important biogenic amines and polypeptides such as:
    • G cells - Gastrin
    • D cells - Somatostatin
    • Enterochromaffin cells - Serotonin
    • ECL cells (enterochromaffin-like cells) - Histamine
    • P/D1 cells - Ghrelin

Stem cells:

  • Undifferentiated cells that multiply and replace other cells

questions.text: A patient with recurrent hemoptysis and renal failure underwent renal biopsy. It revealed the presence of crescents in most of the glomeruli. Immunofluorescence finding is shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, histopathology findings, and immunofluorescence showing linear, dense, and smooth deposits are suggestive of Goodpasture's syndrome.

Goodpasture's syndrome is an anti-GBM (glomerular basement membrane) antibody-mediated disease. The antibodies are directed against the non-collagenous portion of the α3 chain of collagen type IV. As it is present in both the alveoli and GBM, it usually presents with pulmonary hemorrhage and renal failure. It makes up about 1/5 of cases of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

Crescents with linear deposits of IgG and C3 in the glomerular basement membrane are seen on histopathology.

Note: Wegener's granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis) causes the pauci-immune type of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. There is an absence of immune complex deposition on immunofluorescence.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Richter syndrome?
questions.solution:
Richter's syndrome is the transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) to aggressive lymphoma, most commonly diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL). It has a poor prognosis.

Patients develop the following features:

questions.text: Wernicke’s encephalopathy is associated with all except _____
questions.solution:
Amnesia is characteristic of Korsakoff syndrome, not Wernicke's encephalopathy.

Wernicke's encephalopathy is a specific etiology of delirium which is caused by thiamine deficiency, commonly due to alcohol abuse.  

Wernicke's encephalopathy:

  • Acute, neuropsychiatric syndrome characterized by nystagmus and ophthalmoplegia, mental status changes, and unsteadiness of stance and gait.
  • Wernicke’s encephalopathy is a medical emergency, and thiamine should be initiated immediately, either intravenously or intramuscularly.  

Korsakoff syndrome:

  • Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by a pronounced anterograde and retrograde amnesia along with potential impairment in visuospatial, abstract, and other types of learning.
  • Permanent in at least a partial form in about 50 percent of the people affected.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman after a trivial fall presents with pelvic fracture along with left femoral nerve injury. The function of all of the following muscles will be affected except:
questions.solution:
Gracilis is supplied by the obturator nerve and not the femoral nerve. Hence, the function of gracilis muscle will be normal in this patient.

Branches of the femoral nerve:

  • Before entering the thigh, the femoral nerve supplies branches to the iliacus and pectineus muscles
  • The anterior division of femoral nerves supplies the sartorius and gives sensation to the anteromedial aspect of the thigh by the branches medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh and intermediate cutaneous nerve of the thigh
  • The posterior division of the femoral nerve supplies branches to the quadriceps femoris muscles, knee joint and gives sensation to the medial aspect of the leg by the saphenous nerve.

questions.text: A 40-year-man presents with hematuria, polyuria, and hypertension. The resected kidney is as seen below. All are associated with this condition except ______.

choices.text: Cysts in liver, pancreas, and spleen
Portal fibrosis and proliferation of portal bile ducts

questions.solution:
Clinical history and gross image suggest that the patient has autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). They are associated with cysts in liver, spleen, and pancreas; berry aneurysms; and mitral valve prolapse.

Note: 

Patients with autosomal-recessive (childhood) polycystic kidney disease have congenital hepatic fibrosis.

ADPKD

  • Autosomal-dominant disorder
  • Multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure
  • 40% have one to several cysts in the liver (polycystic liver disease)
  • Cysts in the spleen, pancreas, and lungs
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms arise in the circle of Willis à subarachnoid hemorrhages
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1 and PKD2, encoding polycystin 2
  • Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and, therefore, have variable lining epithelia.

questions.text: In a patient with reactive systemic amyloidosis, which of the following proteins are likely to get deposited in the tissues?
questions.solution:
There is the deposition of AA proteins in reactive systemic amyloidosis (secondary amyloidosis).

In inflammatory states, there is a release of IL-1 and IL-6, which act on the liver cells. The liver increases the production of SAA (serum amyloid-associated) proteins which circulate bound to high-density lipoproteins. This gives rise to AA proteins, which get deposited in tissues causing reactive systemic amyloidosis or secondary amyloidosis.

The most common sites are the kidney and heart.

It is usually seen secondary to:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis (most common)
  • Tuberculosis
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Chronic osteomyelitis
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Malignancies - renal cell cancer, Hodgkin’s lymphoma

questions.text: The most abundant cytosolic protein is ________.
questions.solution:
The most abundant cytosolic protein is actin.

  • Collagen is the most abundant protein but it is extracellular.
  • The most abundant overall and extracellular protein: Collagen
  • The most abundant intracellular/cytosolic protein: Actin

An actin protein is the monomeric subunit of two types of filaments in cells: microfilaments, one of the three major components of the cytoskeleton, and thin filaments, part of the contractile apparatus in muscle cells. An actin protein can occur either a free monomer called G-actin (globular) or as part of a linear polymer microfilament called F-actin (filamentous).

  • Actin microfilaments are fibrils (5 to 9-nm diameter) formed from the globular protein actin (G-actin), the most abundant cytosolic protein in cells. G-actin monomers noncovalently polymerize into long filaments (F-actin) that intertwine to form double-stranded helices with a defined polarity; new globular subunits are added (or lost) at the “positive” end of the strand.
  • In muscle cells, the filamentous protein myosin binds to actin, and moves along it, driven by adenosine triphosphate (ATP) hydrolysis (the basis of muscle contraction).
  • In non-muscle cells, F-actin assembles via an assortment of actin-binding proteins into well-organized bundles and networks that control cell shape and movement.

questions.text: Chyme is propelled forward in small intestine by_______
questions.solution:
Chyme is propelled forward in the intestine by the peristaltic movement.

Chyme is a thick semifluid mass of partially digested food and digestive secretions that is expelled by the stomach into the duodenum.

Peristalsis is a propulsive movement, which consists of a segment of contraction behind and relaxation in front.

Segmentation consists of a segment of bowel contracting at both ends, and then a second contraction occurs in the center of the segment to force the chyme both backward and forward. 

It is the small intestine’s primary method of motility during digestion of a meal.

Migrating motor complexes (MMC) are the peristaltic motor patterns that occur during fasting. They migrate from the stomach to the distal ileum.

Haustrations are the characteristic saclike segments seen in the large intestine.

Related Pearl: Types of gastrointestinal motility

questions.text: Groove sign of Greenblatt is seen in ______
questions.solution:
A groove sign of Greenblatt is seen in Lymphogranuloma venerum (LGV). 

It is a pathognomonic sign of LGV in which a groove-like depression is seen between femoral and inguinal lymph nodes - above and below the inguinal ligament seen in 1/3 of cases of Lymphogranuloma venerum (LGV).

Lymphogranuloma venerum affects sexually active adults. The organism spreads from the site of the initial lesion to the regional lymph nodes causing lymphangitis. There is infiltration of polymorphonuclear lymphocytes and plasma cells. The necrotic areas coalesce and enlarge to form a stellate abscess. Patients present with genital ulceration, rectal bleeding, and lymphadenopathy.

There are three stages of the disease: 

Primary - The incubation period is 3-30 days. The genital lesions may be painful or painless. The patient usually presents with symptoms of hemorrhagic proctitis. The condition is common among homosexuals. 

Secondary - It may take days to weeks for the disease to manifest. It is characterized by tender unilateral or bilateral inguinal and/or femoral lymphadenopathy - groove sign. The lymph nodes coalesce to form painful buboes which rupture and form fistulae and sinus tracts. 

Tertiary - Genito-anorectal syndrome is seen. This occurs years after untreated primary infection.  There is lymphatic obstruction due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis. This results in genital lymphoedema and inflammation which causes ulceration and chronic granulomatous fibrosis, resulting in esthiomene in women and elephantiasis in men.

The given image shows esthiomene, a feature of lymphogranuloma venereum. 

 Note: Pseudogroove sign of Greenblatt is seen in Donovanosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with right iliac fossa pain. Imaging shows the presence of an ileocaecal mass. Biopsy of the mass shows a starry sky pattern. What is the translocation involved in this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and biopsy findings are suggestive of Burkitt lymphoma and the translocation involved is t(8;14).

Burkitt lymphoma, also known as small non-cleaved-cell lymphoma, is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It is characterized by the translocation and deregulation of the c-myc gene on chromosome 8. 

The classic t(8;14)(q24;q32) reciprocal translocation results in the transposition of the c-myc proto-oncogene on chromosome 8 with one of the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IGH) genes on chromosome 14. This results in activation of the c-myc gene and is considered responsible for tumor proliferation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an objective of the National Mental Health Programme of 1982?

choices.text: Ensure equal human rights to mentally ill
Promote community participation in mental health services
Promote application of mental health knowledge
Provide accessibility of mental health care

questions.solution:
Ensuring equal rights to mentally ill people is not an objective of the National Mental Health Programme (NMHP). It was launched in 1982 with the following objectives:

  • Ensure availability and accessibility of minimum mental health care
  • Encourage the application of mental health knowledge in general care
  • Promote community participation in mental health services development

The National Mental Health Programme was relaunched as The Mental Health Care Act, 2017 which includes provisions for equal rights for those with mental illness.

World Mental Health Day, observed on October 10th, highlights the importance of mental well-being. This year's theme, "It is Time to Prioritize Mental Health in the Workplace," stresses the need for businesses to foster supportive environments. Safe, healthy workplaces protect mental health, while stigma and poor conditions pose serious risks. By involving those with lived experiences and investing in evidence-based solutions, we can create workplaces where everyone thrives.

questions.text: The following colony morphology on blood agar is indicative of
questions.solution:
The given image shows the frosted glass appearance of the colonies, which is characteristic of Bacillus anthracis.

Bacillus anthracis is the etiologic agent of anthrax—a common disease of livestock and, occasionally, of humans—and the only obligate pathogen within the genus Bacillus. It is a gram-positive, endospore-forming (non-bulging spores), rod-shaped bacterium. Culture characteristics are as follows:

  • On agar, irregularly round colonies are formed, 2 to 3 mm in diameter, raised, dull, opaque, greyish white, with a frosted glass appearance.
  • Under the low-power microscope, the edge of the colony is composed of long, interlacing chains of bacilli, resembling locks of matted hair, called Medusa head appearance.
  • On gelatin stab, they appear as inverted fir tree appearance.
  • On solid media with penicillin, they show a string of pearls appearance in culture smear.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with hyperuricemia and delayed developmental milestones. He also has the habit of biting his lips, fingers, and feet because of which he is always strapped to the bed. Urine examined showed orange sands. Which is the most probable enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. It is caused due to the complete deficiency of Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT).

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder. This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine, from which excessive amounts of uric acid is produced and excreted in urine as orange sands.

Clinical features include compulsive self-mutilation, hyperuricemia, intellectual disability, delayed milestones, dystonic movements and megaloblastic anemia.

Diagnosis is made by deficient HGPRTase enzyme activity in the erythrocyte. Partial deficiency of HGPRTase cause Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Adenine phosphoribosyltransferase enzyme deficiency causes urinary calculus formation with crystalluria.

Option C: Adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency is one of the  2nd major cause of SCID.

Option D: Purine nucleoside phosphorylase causes a severe deficiency of T cells but B cells are normal.

questions.text:
A young man comes with complaints of intermittent bloody diarrhea for 3 weeks after consuming street food during his travel. He is febrile and has RUQ tenderness. Which of the following is the infective form of the likely protozoan causing this disease?

RUQ - Right upper quadrant
questions.solution:
This patient has had bloody diarrhea for 3 weeks after eating street food, making a parasite the likely cause of his dysentery. His diarrhea combined with RUQ tenderness indicating a hepatic abscess makes Entamoeba histolytica the causative organism in this case.  The mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form of Entamoeba histolytica causing amoebic dysentery. It is passed in feces and can remain viable under moist conditions for about 10 days.

The following are the characteristic features of various life stages of Entamoeba histolytica:

The trophozoite is found only in tissues. Its cytoplasm has a ground-glass appearance. The nucleus has a central karyosome with radiating fibrils called linin network giving a cartwheel appearance. Pseudopodia are present which exhibit gliding motility.

The image below shows the trophozoite form.

The precystic stage has a large glycogen vacuole and 2 chromatid bars. It secretes a refractile cyst wall to become a cyst. The cystic stage has a mature cyst with 4 nuclei and no glycogen mass. Chromatid bars disappear.

The below image shows cystic form.

questions.text: A 57-year-old post menopausal lady has been on alendronate for the past two years. By which of the following mechanisms does this drug act?

choices.text: Decreasing the osteoclast mediated resorption of bone

questions.solution:
Alendronate is a bisphosphonate which acts by decreasing osteoclast mediated bone resorption.

Osteoclasts internalize bisphosphonates as they are released along with calcium from the bone surface and then reduce osteoclast activity by:

  • Promoting apoptosis of osteoclasts
  • Disrupting the cytoskeleton and ruffled border of osteoclasts
  • Inhibiting the differentiation of osteoclasts

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with complaints of intermittent discharge from bilateral nipples for the past few months. On compression of her breast during the examination, a discharge was observed as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of a patient with greenish discharge from multiple ducts is duct ectasia.

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of breast ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in non-lactating women. This condition is associated with smoking and diabetes. The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green-colored secretions. In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, causing periductal mastitis. Patients may present with nipple discharge, abscess, fistula, or nipple retraction.

Treatment includes:

  • Initial stages - oral antibiotics, needle aspiration, or incision and drainage of the abscess
  • Recurrent episodes - Hadfield operation (cone excision of multiple ducts)
  • A single duct involvement - microdochectomy.

Related Pearl: Discharge from the Nipple

  • Skin diseases (eczema, psoriasis)
  • Rare causes (e.g., chancre)

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with chest pain on the left side radiating to the arm and jaw on the same side. Cardiac troponins are found to be raised. What is the diagnosis based on this ECG?
questions.solution:
The given ECG is of posterior wall MI.

  • Tall and broad R waves (>30ms) in V2 and V3
  • Dominant R waves (R/S ratio > 1) in V2

questions.text: The order of depolarization after stimulation of Purkinje fibers is:
questions.solution:
The order of depolarization is from septum → endocardium→ epicardium.

The spread of Cardiac Excitation:

Atrial depolarization is initiated from SA node spreads radially through atria, then converges on the AV node. A delay of about 0.1s (AV nodal delay) occurs before excitation spreads to the ventricles.
Ventricular depolarization starts at the left side of the interventricular septum and moves first to the right across the midportion of the septum. It moves along the ventricular walls to the AV groove, proceeding from the endocardial to the epicardial surface.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presented with left-sided nasal blockage and discharge for 3 years. On anterior rhinoscopy, a pale, red polypoidal mass is seen in the left nostril. He was diagnosed with inverted papilloma. Which of the following statements is false about the management of his condition?

choices.text: MRI is the first imaging modality in follow-up

questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is not advised in inverted papilloma since it may induce malignancy.

Option A: Endoscopic approach is preferred to surgical resection.

Option C: There is a high rate of recurrence of inverted papillomas.

Option D: MRI is the first imaging modality to perform during follow up.

Related Pearl: Inverted Papilloma

Inverted papilloma is also known as transitional cell papilloma or Ringertz tumor or Schneiderian papilloma. It is a common benign tumour of the paranasal sinuses. It is a premalignant condition with 10-15% chances of turning malignant.

Etiology: Human papillomavirus has been implicated in its etiology.

Origin: Arises from the lateral wall of the nose from the non-olfactory epithelium of the nose

Clinical features:

  • More common in men.
  • Predominance between 40-70 years.
  • Unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis are the main presenting symptoms
  • It is a locally invasive tumor and can invade orbit and paranasal sinuses.
  • Proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation can result from orbital invasion

Findings: It is seen as a pale polypoidal mass resembling a simple nasal polyp.

Investigations: A biopsy is needed for diagnosis.

Treatment: Medial maxillectomy via lateral rhinotomy or midfacial degloving approach. Radiotherapy can lead to malignancy.

questions.text: A 32 year old lady is undergoing evaluation for polycystic ovary syndrome. Her sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) is low. The decrease in sex hormone-binding globulin will have the maximum effect on which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
The decrease in sex hormone-binding globulin will have the maximum effect on testosterone.

Around 98% of the circulating testosterone is bound to plasma proteins such as sex hormone-binding globulin (65%) and albumin. So, the decrease in sex-hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) or gonadal steroid-binding globulin (GBG) will have the maximum effect on testosterone levels by increasing the levels of its free form.

Therefore patients with polycystic ovary syndrome will show features of hyperandrogenism (due to elevated free testosterone).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most sensitive test to detect early diabetic nephropathy in a patient?
questions.solution:
Microalbuminuria is the most sensitive and earliest finding of diabetic nephropathy. It refers to urine albumin of 30–300 mg/24-hour urine.  It is seen in the stage of incipient diabetic kidney disease. 

However, microalbuminuria is a very variable finding and is not required to diagnose nephropathy. Non-albuminuric diabetic nephropathy may occur in some patients and regression of albuminuria may be seen in type 1 diabetics.

Diabetic nephropathy can be diagnosed if the following are satisfied: 

  • Reduced GFR (< 60 mL/min/1.73 m2) with or without persistent albuminuria (> 30 mg/day or urine PCR > 30 mg/g)
  • Long duration of diabetes or established diabetic retinopathy
  • Other etiologies are ruled out

questions.text: A young patient with visual disturbances was found to have a brain tumour. He was referred to ophthalmology for a complete visual field assessment before planning his resection. Humprey analyzer revealed the following plot. What is the most likely site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The visual field defect shown is the typical "pie in the sky" defect or superior quadrantic hemianopia. They are produced when the inferior fibers of the optic radiations in the temporal lobe (Meyer's loop) are involved.

"Pie in the floor" defects refer to inferior quadrantic hemianopia. It is seen in the involvement of the superior fibers of optic radiations in the parietal lobe (Baum's loop).

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions should cholinomimetic drugs be avoided?
questions.solution:
Cholinomimetics cannot be used in bradycardia. They cause bradycardia by its action on M2 receptors on the heart.

In bradycardia, an anticholinergic agent like atropine is indicated.

Other options:

Option A - Cholinomimetics like pilocarpine are used in both open-angle and closed-angle glaucoma.

Option C - Cobra venom contains a curare-like neurotoxin. Although antivenom is the specific antidote, symptoms can be controlled by a combination of neostigmine and atropine.

Option D - Cholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine and pyridostigmine are indicated in myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: The nerve most commonly used for peripheral nerve monitoring is ______
questions.solution:
Ulnar nerve is most commonly used for peripheral nerve testing.

Other nerves used are the median, posterior tibial, common peroneal, and facial nerves.

questions.text: Abdominal examination during a routine antenatal checkup gave a positive Stallworthy sign. What could be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Stallworthy sign is observed in posterior placenta previa.

The slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis, which recovers promptly when the pressure is relieved, is called Stallworthy sign.

Note: This sign is not always significant as this could also occur in normal pregnancies due to fetal head compression.

questions.text: T sign is seen in _______
questions.solution:
T sign is seen in a monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

It helps to differentiate between monochorionic and dichorionic pregnancies. While T sign is seen in monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy, Lambda sign is seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancies have a dividing membrane that is thin (less than 2 mm) and formed by amnions of each twin. A “T” is formed at the point at which amnions meet the placenta. It may not be seen until the second trimester.

questions.text: The treatment for acute hepatitis C is
questions.solution:
Ribavirin and Pegylated IFN are used in acute hepatitis C infection.

  • Ribavarin and Pegylated interferon would be the best option.
  • Ribavirin is added if HCV RNA failed to clear after 3 months of peginterferon, but some authorities recommended using ribavirin with peginterferon from the start of therapy.
  • Treatment during the acute infection period consists of monitoring HCV RNA for at least 12 weeks to 16 weeks before starting treatment is recommended to allow for spontaneous clearance.

Note: If the options include newer regimens such as directly acting antivirals (DAA), then it would be a better option. Besides, consider the time frame if mentioned in question.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common protein mutation seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
The most common mutations in HCM are those affecting the myosin heavy chain.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy was brought to the ER in an unconscious state. His coworker states he works in a factory manufacturing pesticides. Based on this, the medical officer suspects cyanide poisoning and administers sodium nitrite. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of this drug in this case?
questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of sodium nitrite as an antidote for cyanide poisoning is by the development of methemoglobinemia.

Cyanide binds to the cytochrome oxidase (complex IV) of the electron transport chain (ETC), thereby blocking it. When sodium nitrite is administered, it releases the nitrite ion. This ion binds to hemoglobin to form methemoglobin. The methemoglobin so formed, has a high affinity for the cyanide ion and binds to it, thus, detaching it from the cytochrome oxidase. This regenerates active cytochrome normalizing the function of ETC. 

The cyanide ion with methemoglobin forms cyanmethemoglobin. Sodium thiosulphate is administered for the elimination of this compound. The thiosulfate  forms thiocyanate ion with the cyanide and this is readily excreted.

questions.text: MAC value of an inhaled anesthetic is a measure of_____

questions.text: By what age is the milestone shown in the image typically attained?
questions.solution:
The milestone shown in the image is a mature pincer grasp, which is seen at the age of 12 months. It is identified as a mature pincer grasp as the object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

  • At 6 months, the infant reaches and holds a larger object in a crude manner using the ulnar aspect of his hand (Ulnar palmar grasp). At 8-9 months, the object is grasped by the radial side of the palm (radial palmar grasp).
  • At 9 months, the immature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the adducted thumb and the extended index finger.
  • At 12 months, the mature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

questions.text: How much urine in the bladder will cause the first urge to void in a patient?
questions.solution:
The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL, and a marked sense of fullness at about 400 mL.

Cystometrogram (refer figure)

A plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder is called a cystometrogram.

The curve shows

  • An initial slight rise in pressure when the first increments in the volume are produced(Ia);
  • A long, nearly flat segment as further increments are produced(Ib);
  • A sudden, sharp rise in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered(II).
  • The flatness of segment Ib is a manifestation of the law of Laplace.
  • This law states that the pressure in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension divided by the radius.
  • P= 2T/R
  • In the case of the blad­der, the tension increases as the organ fill but so does the radius. Therefore, the pressure increase is slight until the organ is relatively full.

questions.text: A patient with HIV presented complaining of cough and progressively worsening breathing difficulty. Chest X-ray showed bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The Gomori methamine silver-stained smear of his bronchoalveolar lavage is given below. What is the most probable causative organism and the typical CD4+ count this infection occurs at?
questions.solution:
Cough, progressive dyspnea, bilateral interstitial infiltrates and the Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stained smear showing black-colored cysts resembling crushed ping pong balls are suggestive of pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). It is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii and occurs at a CD4+ count <200/µl.

Pneumocystis jirovecii is an opportunistic fungus causing pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals. It has three morphological forms: trophozoite, pre-cyst and cyst. The infection is transmitted through respiratory droplets. Patients present with fever, non-productive cough and progressive dyspnea. Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The classic finding of dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS.

It can be diagnosed by demonstration of the organism in broncho-alveolar lavage or lung biopsy specimens. PCR can also be done. Treatment of choice is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and pentamidine isethionate. Cotrimoxazole can also be used for prophylaxis in patients with AIDS.

The following X-ray image shows a cyst (arrow) and bilateral lung infiltrates in a patient with PCP:

Note: Toxoplasma gondii is an opportunistic infection causing encephalitis. On GMS staining of infected tissue, tachyzoites appear as crescent-shaped structures with blue cytoplasm and dark nucleus. Toxoplasmosis typically occurs in AIDS patients with a CD4+ count <100/µl.

Pre-Botzinger complex generates the rhythm for automated breathing.

  • These are the first set of neurons that initiate inspiration.
  • These neurons discharge rhythmically, and they produce rhythmic discharges in the phrenic motor neurons.

Breathing is under the control of both the following:

  • Voluntary control: Located in the cerebral cortex (via corticospinal tract)
  • Automatic control: Driven by pacemaker cells in the medulla (Pre-Botzinger complex). These activate motor neurons via cervical (Phrenic nerve innervating diaphragm) and thoracic spinal cord (external intercostal muscle).

There is a reciprocal innervation to expiratory and inspiratory muscles in that motor neurons supplying expiratory muscles are inactive when motor neurons supplying inspiratory muscles are active, and vice versa.

Maintenance Apneustic center in lower Pons stimulates Dorsal group of neurons in the medulla
Termination  Apneustic center inhibited by Vagus and Pneumotaxic center

Regulation of expiration: During quiet breathing, expiration is a passive process; there is no firing of neurons. Ventral respiratory group of neurons are involved in forceful expiration like during exercise.

Mnemonic DIVE: Dorsal respiratory group for Inspiration and Ventral respiratory group for Expiration.

questions.text: Which of the following methods of sterilization involves exposure to 100 °C for 20 minutes on 3 successive days?
questions.solution:
The method of sterilization that involves exposure at 100°C for 20 minutes for 3 successive days is called tyndallization or intermittent sterilization. 

Tyndallization, which utilizes steam, was used for sterilization of media containing gelatin, egg, serum, or sugar. This method may not kill spores of certain anaerobes and thermophiles. Autoclaving has replaced this method now. 

Other options:

Option A: Autoclaving involves heating at 121°C for 15 minutes at a pressure of 15psi. This is the used for intruments, linen, laboratory ware.

Option C: In pasteurization, milk is heated at either 63°C for 30 minutes (the holder method) or at 72°C for 15–20 seconds (the flash process), followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower. 

Option D: Heating an article at 80–85 °C for 30 minutes on 3 consecutive days is called inspissation.

questions.text: A woman, weighing 58 kg, has second-degree burns covering 20% of the total body surface area.  Which of the following formulae would you use to calculate the amount of fluid to be given?

choices.text: Percentage of burns × weight (kg) × 2 = volume in mL
Percentage of burns × weight (kg)/2 =  volume in mL
Percentage of burns × weight (kg) × 4 = volume in mL
Weight + 1500 ml/m2×BSA burnt = volume in mL

questions.solution:
According to the latest ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) 10th edition 2018, resuscitation formula for second and third-degree thermal burns in the first 24 hours is given by the following equation:

Total percentage body surface area burned × weight (kg) × 2 = volume (mL).

Half this volume is given in the first 8 hours and the second half is given in the subsequent 16 hours. This has been recommended to reflect concerns about over-resuscitation when using the traditional Parkland formula. 

Adequacy of fluid resuscitation is assessed by monitoring for a urine output of 0.5-1.0 mL/kg/hr.

However, in cases of electrical burns, the formula is: 

Total percentage body surface area burned× weight (kg) × 4 = volume (mL).

Parkland and Modified Parkland formula:

  • Parkland's formula for resuscitation in the initial 24 hours is given by =  Total percentage body surface area × weight (kg) × 4 = volume (mL).
  • Modified Parkland's formula provides more specific recommendations for the second 24 hours, advising colloid infusion of 5% albumin at the amount of 0.3-1.0/mL/kg/%BSA/hr. The management of the first 24 hours remains the same.

NOTE : Resuscitation formulas are not used in cases of superficial burns and in non-superficial burns with <20% TBSA

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is rushed to the casualty with sudden-onset breathing difficulty. History reveals that her father also suffers from similar episodes. Examination findings are as follows. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Type II of this condition is most common
The enzyme involved is C1 INH
There is loss of inhibition of Hageman factor
Associated with  C4 and C2 deficiency

questions.solution:
The image shows subcutaneous and submucosal edema of the face and lips without wheals. Along with the history, a diagnosis of hereditary angioedema (HAE) is most likely. Type I HAE is the most common form (85%).

There are three types of hereditary angioedema (HAE):

  • Type 1 (85%): C1INH deficiency 
  • Type 2 (15%): Dysfunction of C1-INH, but normal levels
  • Type 3 (rare) :  Normal C1-INH levels and function

HAE occurs due to a mutation in the SERPING1 gene, which codes for the C1 esterase inhibitor (C1INH). It is also called angioneurotic edema or Quincke's disease.

C1INH enzyme normally inhibits the following:

  • Complement system
  • Kallikrein system
  • Factor XII or Hageman factor

In HAE, loss of C1INH activity leads to loss of inhibition of these above processes. This leads to decreased C4 and C2 levels and bradykinin accumulation.

questions.text: Which of the following does not follow transport saturation kinetics?
questions.solution:
Simple diffusion is not carrier-mediated transport hence do not follow saturation kinetics.

  • Facilitated diffusion, primary active transport, and secondary active transport all involve integral membrane proteins and are called carrier-mediated transport.
  • All carrier-mediated transport system follows saturation kinetics.
  • The figure shows that as the concentration of the diffusing substance increases, the rate of simple diffusion continues to increase proportionately, but in the case of facilitated diffusion, the rate of diffusion cannot rise greater than the transport maximum (Tm). Tm is analogous to the maximum velocity (Vmax) level in enzyme kinetics.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of Carrier Mediated Transport

Properties Description
Stereospecificity For example- D-Glucose is transport by facilitated diffusion but not L-isomer. Simple diffusion in contrast will not distinguish between the two.
Saturation The transport rate increases as the concentration of the solute increases until the carriers are saturated (Tm).
Competition Structurally related solutes compete for transport sites on carrier molecules.

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of visualizing regions while performing FAST in a patient suspected to have abdominal trauma?
  1. Subxiphoid
  2. Left upper quadrant
  3. Right upper quadrant
  4. Suprapubic
questions.solution:
The correct sequence to visualize regions in FAST is subxiphoid → right upper quadrant → left upper quadrant → suprapubic.

Focussed assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) is a non-invasive investigation that can be performed rapidly in the emergency room. It helps identify an abnormal collection of fluid or blood.

FAST is indicated in:

  • Haemodynamically unstable patients who had a blunt abdominal trauma
  • Patients who sustained penetrating abdominal trauma with no other indications for immediate laparotomy (signs of hemodynamic instability, peritoneal irritation, peritoneal penetration, and gunshot wound with transperitoneal trajectory).

Technique:

  • The patient is placed in a supine position.
  • With a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer, the following regions are scanned:
    • Subxiphoid transverse view is used to assess pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries.
    • A longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant is used to assess right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison's pouch.
    • A longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant is used to assess splenic injury and left kidney injury.
    • Transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region are used to assess Douglas's bladder and pouch.

An "extended FAST or eFAST" scan: Assess left and right thoracic views, in addition to the FAST assessed regions, to look for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

questions.text: The given incidental finding in the ileum was noted while performing an appendectomy for a child. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Gastric mucosa is the most common heterotropic mucosa seen
Intestinal obstruction is the most common presentation in children

questions.solution:
The above finding depicts Meckel's diverticulum. Intestinal obstruction is the most common presentation in adults with Meckel’s diverticula. Bleeding is the most common manifestation in children.

Meckel's diverticulum has a 2:1 male-to-female preponderance and is the most common congenital anomaly of the small intestine. It is situated on the antimesenteric border of the ileum, usually 45 to 60 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve, and occurs due to incomplete closure of the vitelline duct. It is a true diverticulum consisting of all layers. 

It can present as:

  • Incidental findings during surgery
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in the form of hemorrhage in children
  • Intestinal obstruction in the form of volvulus, intussusception (urge to defecate, vomiting, red current stools) 
  • Diverticulitis (right lower quadrant pain)

In children, 99mTc-pertechnetate is preferentially taken up by the mucus-secreting cells of gastric mucosa and ectopic gastric tissue in Meckel's diverticulum and is the most accurate diagnostic modality. However, in adults, less ectopic gastric tissue is seen, so the test is not very accurate. The sensitivity and specificity can be improved by the use of cimetidine.

In case of false-negative results, barium studies, mesenteric arteriography, or double-balloon endoscopy can be used for diagnosis.

Treatment is diverticulectomy or segmental resection of ileum containing diverticulum. In children, an incidentally found asymptomatic diverticulum has to be resected. 

Related Pearl: Rule of two’s in Meckel's diverticulum

  • 2% prevalence
  • 2:1 male predominance
  • Located approx 2 feet (60 cm) proximal to the ileocecal valve in adults
  • Approx 2 inches in length
  • Half of those who are symptomatic are under 2 years of age.
  • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)

questions.text: The given instrument can be used to measure all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The image shown above is of the kata thermometer. It was originally used to measure the cooling power of air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently, it is only used to measure low air velocities.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: You are assisting your senior resident who is performing the procedure shown in the image. He engages you with some historical trivia and asks you who performed this procedure first. What would your answer be?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the above picture is spinal anesthesia.

The first case of spinal anesthesia in humans was performed by August Bier in 1898. He performed spinal anesthesia using the local anesthetic cocaine.

Spinal anesthesia involves the administration of a local anesthetic into the spinal subarachnoid space to provide motor and sensory blockade. Another contribution by August Bier is 'Bier's block' or IVRA (intravenous regional anesthesia).

 

John Lundy: coined the term balanced anesthesia. 

Carl Koller:  proposed local anesthetic property of cocaine. 

Oliver Wendell: coined the term anesthesia.

questions.text: 2-year-old Neha has been having fever since yesterday and is refusing food. Parents became alarmed when she developed an abnormal barking cough today morning and have brought her to the casualty. On examination, the child looked exhausted and had visible chest retractions and stridor. The temperature was 39.6 degrees and SpO2 was 93% on room air. Chest X-ray reveals a 'steeple' sign. What is the treatment of choice in this child?

choices.text: Send a throat swab and start IV antibiotics

questions.solution:
Fever, barking cough, inspiratory stridor and a steeple sign on chest radiograph are suggestive of acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup). The treatment of choice in this child is nebulization with racemic epinephrine. 

Epinephrine acts rapidly and provides immediate relief. It constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure. This increases fluid resorption and reduces airway edema.

questions.text: Identify the type of study from the following design:
questions.solution:
The design given is of a case-control study. It proceeds from effect to cause and is done after the exposure and outcome have occurred.

It tries to determine the possible exposure factors after a known disease incidence. This is the first approach to test causal hypotheses and uses controls to support or refute an inference.

Retrospective or historical cohort study, on the other hand, tries to compare the risk of developing a disease to some already known exposure factors. Ex: risk of lung cancer in uranium miners, risk of angiosarcoma in persons exposed to polyvinyl chloride etc.

Retrospective cohort studies are more economical and quicker than prospective cohort studies.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: A 30-year-old professional mountain climber presents with the following lesions over his leg. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows serpiginous or serpent-like skin lesions, which are characteristically seen in cutaneous larva migrans or ground itch.

It is caused by the larvae of various hookworm or Ancylostoma species. The parasite is acquired from direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog or cat feces. It is common following travel to endemic or tropical areas and symptoms develop within the first 2 weeks. 

The site of entry is marked by an inflamed papule, often located between the toes. Serpentine or linear single-track lines later appear as the larvae migrate through the epidermis. The lesions can enlarge as much as 1 to 2 cm per day.

The first-line treatment is oral ivermectin at 200 μg/kg. Oral albendazole is an alternative treatment.

Note: Larva currens is caused by the migrating larva of Strongyloides stercoralis. It also produces serpiginous lesions and can be differentiated by the faster rate of progression and haphazard distribution of lesions.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with overt diabetes comes to you for pre-conception counseling. Which of the following congenital heart defects are least likely to occur if she were to have a child?
questions.solution:

Ventricular septal defect and transposition of great arteries are the most common cardiac anomalies in infants of diabetic mothers.

The most common cardiac anomaly in an infant of a diabetic mother is a controversial topic. Most resources mention VSD and TGA are the most common and do not specify which among them is more common.

Large doses of iodide given to a patient with a hyperplastic endemic goitre that is iodine avid may produce temporary hyperthyroidism and, very occasionally, persistent hyperthyroidism which is referred to as Jod -basedow effect.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Bowen’s disease?

choices.text: Occasionally it may undergo spontaneous partial resolution

questions.solution:
Bowen's disease has a low potential for invasive malignancy. 

It is an intraepidermal squamous cell carcinoma that is characterized by a persistent, non‐elevated, red, scaly, or crusted plaque with a small potential for invasive malignancy. Histologically, it is characterized by full-thickness epidermal dysplasia.

It usually grows progressively but sometimes undergoes spontaneous partial resolution. It can occur anywhere, but it occurs more in the head and neck region.

Human papilloma virus infection is associated with it.

Image: Red scaly plaque seen on the finger, in an 81-year-old woman with Bowen’s disease.

questions.text: A woman with cervical incompetence is posted for prophylactic McDonald's cerclage. Which of the following statements is false about this procedure?

choices.text: Removal of stitch must be done by 37th week
A mersilene tape is tied around the cervix
Done at the level of internal os

questions.solution:
In McDonald's cerclage, a nonabsorbable suture, such as Mersilene, is placed as a purse-string suture as high as possible at the level of the internal os, positioned at the junction where the rugose vaginal epithelium transitions to the smooth vaginal portion of the cervix, below the bladder.

Another cerclage procedure is Modified Shirodker's technique. In this, a non-absorbable (mersilene) tape is passed subcutaneously through a transverse anterior incision and is tied posteriorly.

Removal of cerclage should be done by 37 weeks of gestation. It can be removed earlier in case of preterm labour.

Complications of cervical cerclage:

  • Slipping of suture
  • Chorioamnionitis
  • Rupture of membranes
  • Abortion or preterm labour
  • Cervical laceration or scarring

Many patients do not have the classic history that indicates prophylactic cerclage in the late first or early second trimester. Therefore, many cerclage procedures are performed emergently rather than prophylactically

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is metabolised by plasma cholinesterase?
questions.solution:
Cocaine is metabolized by butyrylcholinesterase/ pseudocholinesterase. 

Cocaine is primarily metabolized in the liver, but, it is alternatively metabolized by pseudocholinesterase also.

Morphine, methamphetamine, and barbiturates are metabolized only in the liver.

questions.text: In which of the following are the pores of Kohn located?
questions.solution:
Pores of Kohn (alveolar pores) are seen in the alveolar wall.

They are the interalveolar connections that permit the passage of bacteria and exudate between adjacent alveoli. This plays an important role in the pathogenesis of lobar pneumonia. During the gray hepatization phase, fibrin also spreads through these pores.

When the lung is partially deflated, collateral ventilation can also occur to some extent through these pores.

questions.text: Which type of tubal pregnancy ruptures at a later stage?
questions.solution:
Interstitial tubal pregnancy ruptures at a later stage i.e. at 12-16 weeks. This is because pregnancy at this site is closer to the uterine myometrium which provides support as pregnancy progresses. 

Isthmic and ampullary pregnancies terminate by tubal rupture. However, isthmic pregnancy ruptures earlier. Ampullary and infundibular pregnancy can terminate by tubal abortion as well.

She brings the child to you and informs you about the past history of seizures. Investigations reveal elevated plasma ammonia levels and argininosuccinate levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is argininosuccinic aciduria due to argininosuccinate lyase deficiency.

It is accompanied by high levels of argininosuccinate levels in blood, CSF, and urine. It is also associated with friable, tufted hair known as trichorrhexis nodosa.

questions.text: A cardiologist while reviewing a case of MI, notes that the patient has right dominant circulation. Which of the following determines coronary dominance?
questions.solution:
Coronary dominance is determined by the posterior interventricular artery (PIVA).

In about 65% of the population, the PIVA is given by the right coronary artery and this is called the right cardiac dominance.

In 10% of the population, it is a branch of the left coronary artery alone, called the left cardiac dominance.

In the remaining 25% population, it is given by both (balanced dominance).

questions.text: Abdominal examination of a 28-year-old primigravida, who is in the second stage of labour, reveals retraction ring between the active upper segment and the distended lower segment. Which would best describe this ring?
questions.solution:
Bandl's ring refers to pathological retraction ring. It is formed in cases of obstructed labour.

The upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigourously in an attempt to overcome the obstruction while the lower segment dilates.

With each contraction there is myometrial shortening so that the actively contracting upper segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter. The passive lower segment is progressively stretched and becomes thinner.

The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring.

Schroeder's constriction ring is formed due to incordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibres of the uterus. It is formed due to injudicious use of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes (PROM).

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complaining of irritation in her left eye has the following finding. Which of the following condition commonly causes this?
questions.solution:
Irritation in the eye associated with areas of scleral thinning through which the uvea shines is suggestive of scleromalacia perforans. It is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of progressive scleral thinning without inflammation. Despite the term 'scleromalacia perforans', perforation is extremely rare as the integrity of the sclera is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue.

Other collagen disorders associated with it are as follows:

  • Wegener’s granulomatosis (option B)
  • Polyarteritis nodosa (option A)
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Relapsing polychondritis

questions.text:
A 25-year-old primigravida with a history of gestational diabetes mellitus is in active labour. After delivery of the head, turtle sign was noticed. Which of the following can be used for the management of this patient?
  1. Mc Robert's maneuver
  2. Wood's corkscrew maneuver
  3. Modified Ritgen's maneuver
  4. Rubin's maneuver
  5. Pinard's maneuver
  6. Gaskin's maneuver
questions.solution:
A patient with gestational diabetes and the presence of turtle sign is suggestive of shoulder dystocia. Mc Robert's manoeuvre, Wood's corkscrew manoeuvre, Gaskin's manoeuvre, and Rubin's manoeuvre are all used in its management. 

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal pelvis. Turtle sign may be seen which refers to the recoil of the fetal head against the perineum.

Management of labour in case of shoulder dystocia:

  • 1st line of management - Mc Roberts manoeuvre (flexion and abduction of thigh)
  • 2nd line of management - Rubin's (rotation of the easily accessible shoulder by 30-45°), Woods corkscrew manoeuvre (rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a cork screw fashion) ; OR Gaskin (all four's position)
  • Last line of management - Zavanelli manoeuvre (head is rotated to its pre-restitution position and caesarian section is performed); OR procedures such as cleidotomy (fracture of the clavicle of the baby); symphysiotomy (divide pubic symphysis of mother)

In a case of bilateral shoulder dystocia, directly proceed to perform cesarean section after doing Zavanelli manoeuvre.

questions.text: A patient who presented to the OPD with a papulosquamous lesion has the following nail finding. Histopathology of the skin lesion is unlikely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given image showing nail pitting and salmon patches in fingernails are characteristic of psoriasis. Munro microabscess is seen in psoriasis whereas Pautrier's microabscess is seen in mycosis fungoides.

Histopathological features of psoriasis:

  • Irregular epidermal thickening (acanthosis)
  • Hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis
  • Suprapapillary thinning
  • Clubbing of rete ridges at the base
  • Kogoj spongiform pustules (collection of neutrophils in Malpighian layer)
  • Munro microabscesses (collection of neutrophils in stratum corneum)
  • Absence of stratum granulosum
  • Dilated, tortuous blood vessels in the dermis
  • Suprapapillary mononuclear leukocytic infiltrates

Remember:  M (Munro microabscess) is seen in P (Psoriasis) and P (Pautrier’s microabscess) is seen in M (mycosis fungoides)

questions.text: Which of the following is not true with regard to selectins?

choices.text: There are L, E and P types of selectins
P-selectins are expressed on the endothelium

questions.solution:
Selectins are a group of molecules that mediate low-affinity interactions between the leukocytes and the endothelium.

Due to the low-affinity nature of these interactions, they are easily disrupted by the flowing blood. They play a major role in the initial rolling interactions of leukocytes with the vascular endothelium. The expression of selectins and their ligands is regulated by cytokines produced in response to infection and injury.

There are 3 types of selectins:

  1. L-selectin - expressed on leukocytes
  2. E-selectin - expressed on endothelium
  3. P-selectin - expressed on activated platelets and endothelium

questions.text: A newly married woman was found dead in her house. On inquiry, it was informed by the neighbours that the couple used to fight a lot regarding dowry. Which section deals with this scenario?
questions.solution:
Dowry Death is defined under section 80 of Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) 2023 (IPC 304B).

  • If a husband or his relative subjects the woman to cruelty or harassment in demand of dowry within 7 years of marriage, they shall be deemed to have caused her death.
  • The punishment for such cases is imprisonment for not less than 7 years but may be extended to life imprisonment.

Option A: Section 63 (IPC 375) deals with rape.

Option C: Section 72 (IPC 228A) deals with imprisonment for up to 2 years and a fine for disclosure of the identity of a rape victim.

Option D: Section 100 (IPC 299) deals with culpable homicide.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female present with unsteady gait, forgetfulness, and labile moods. One physical exam, the neurologist notices that her iris appear multicolored with concentric rings around the periphery. The most likely gene mutation is______
questions.solution:
• Clinical history and presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings suggest a diagnosis of Wilson disease.
  • HFE mutation – Hereditary Haemochromatosis
  • PNPLA3 polymorphism – NAFLD
  • CFTR-Cystic fibrosis
  • Wilson disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutation of the ATP7B gene, resulting in impaired copper excretion into bile and a failure to incorporate copper into ceruloplasmin.
  • Located on chromosome 13
  • This disorder is marked by the accumulation of toxic levels of copper in principally the liver, brain, and eye.
  • In the liver, copper binds to a α2-globulin (apoceruloplasmin) to form ceruloplasmin. Circulating ceruloplasmin is eventually degraded within lysosomes, after which the released copper is excreted into bile. This degradation/excretion pathway is the primary route for copper elimination. Deficiency in the ATP7B protein causes a decrease in copper transport into bile, impairs its incorporation into ceruloplasmin, and inhibits ceruloplasmin secretion into the blood. These changes cause copper accumulation in the liver and a decrease in circulating ceruloplasmin. The accumulated copper causes toxic liver injury
  • Histology
    • Excess copper deposition can often be demonstrated by special stains (rhodamine stain for copper, orcein stain for copper-associated protein).
    • Fatty change (steatosis)
    • Hepatocyte ballooning with prominent Mallory-Denk bodies.
  • Demonstration of hepatic copper content in excess of 250 µg per gram dry weight is most helpful for making a diagnosis.
  • Toxic injury to the brain primarily affects the basal ganglia, particularly the putamen, which shows atrophy and even cavitation.
  • Kayser-Fleischer rings, green to brown deposits of copper in Descemet membrane in the limbus of the cornea.

Biochemical diagnosis of Wilson disease is based on

  • Decrease in serum ceruloplasmin,
  • an increase in hepatic copper content (the most sensitive and accurate test), and
  • increased urinary excretion of copper (the most specific screening test).
  • Neurologic involvement presents as movement disorders (tremor, poor coordination, chorea or choreoathetosis) or rigid dystonia (spastic dystonia, mask-like facies, rigidity and gait disturbances
  • Psychiatric symptoms such as depression, phobias, compulsive behavior, and labile mood.
  • Hemolytic anemia may occur due to the toxicity of copper to red cell membranes.

Image – Kayser-Fleischer ring in Wilson disease.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing direct laryngoscopy, subglottic stenosis is noted. Which grading system will you use to report the extent of the stenosis?
questions.solution:
Myer Cotton’s grading is used for subglottic stenosis.

It is the abnormal thickening of cricoid/fibrous tissue proliferation below cords. It causes the airway to narrow and presents with dyspnea, biphasic stridor and a normal cry. 

Diagnosis:

  • In full-term infants, subglottic diameter <4mm.
  • In premature infants, subglottic diameter <3mm.

The Myer Cotton’s grading system allows to stratify the stenosis and plan for treatment:

  • Grade 1: <50% stenosis
  • Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis
  • Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis
  • Grade 4: No lumen detected

Other options

  • Option A - Hyams grading is a predictive tool used in olfactory neuroblastoma.
  • Option B - House Brackmann grading is used as a facial nerve grading system.
  • Option D - Modified mallampati classification is used to assess difficult airway

questions.text: In which of the following conditions will you perform the Kasai procedure?
questions.solution:
Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy) is done for extrahepatic biliary atresia. In the Kasai procedure, the occluded extrahepatic bile ducts are excised and a jejunal Roux loop is anastomosed to the hepatic hilum.

Extrahepatic biliary atresia (EHBA) is defined as a partial or total absence of permeable bile duct between porta hepatis and the duodenum. It is due to inflammatory fibrosis of the biliary tree. It leads to obstruction to bile flow thereby causing leaking of conjugated bilirubin into the circulation.

Associated anomalies include cardiac lesions, polysplenia, situs inversus, absent vena cava, and a preduodenal portal vein.

HIDA scan is the investigation of choice for EHBA. Intraoperative cholangiogram is the gold standard for diagnosis.

Management of extrahepatic biliary atresia
Type I

Atresia restricted to the common bile duct

Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy
Type II

Atresia of the common hepatic duct

 Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy)
Type III

Atresia of the right and left hepatic duct

Infants with biliary atresia, who do not achieve successful drainage after Kasai's procedure, require liver transplantation within the first year of life. It is the most common reason for liver transplantation in children.
