questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of low-grade fever, dry cough, and progressive dyspnea. Examination reveals the following painless skin lesion. Chest X-ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Lung biopsy shows non-caseating granulomas. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?

choices.text: Anergy to common skin test antigens

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing the lesion of lupus pernio point towards sarcoidosis. It is a multisystemic disease characterized by polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia.

Lupus pernio is seen in cutaneous sarcoidosis and presents as infiltrated erythematoviolaceous plaques involving the nose, cheeks, ears, lips, forehead, and fingers. On the cheeks, telangiectasia is characteristic. It is usually painless. As it does not ulcerate, it is not as mutilating as lupus vulgaris.

Immunological abnormalities include:

  • Polyclonal hyperglobulinemia
  • A CD4/CD8 ratio > 3.5
  • T- cell expansion and macrophage activation
  • Impaired dendritic cell function
  • Anergy to common skin tests.

The hallmarks of sarcoidosis include:

  • B/L hilar lymphadenopathy
  • Non-caseating granulomas
  • Lupus pernio
  • Erythema nodosum (acute sarcoidosis)

Syndromes associated with sarcoidosis are:

  • Mikulicz syndrome - sarcoidosis combined with uveoparotid involvement
  • Lofgren's syndrome - acute presentation of sarcoidosis, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum, and bilateral hilar adenopathy

The image below shows the characteristic non-caseating sarcoid granuloma.

The image below shows stellate inclusions known as asteroid bodies that are found within giant cells in approximately 60% of the granulomas.

The image below shows laminated concretions composed of calcium and proteins known as Schaumann bodies that are found within giant cells in approximately 60% of the granulomas.

questions.text: Carotid sinus baroreceptor is most sensitive to _____
questions.solution:
The carotid sinus baroreceptor is most sensitive to pulse pressure. They fire more rapidly to a constantly changing pressure than a stationary one.  

Baroreceptors

  1. Stretch receptors located in the heart and adventitia of the blood vessels
  2. Types based on location
    • Carotid sinus and aortic arch receptors (high-pressure regions)
    • Cardiopulmonary receptors (low-pressure regions)
  3. Afferents
    • Carotid sinus – a branch of Glossopharyngeal nerve (IX CN) – the carotid sinus nerve (sinus nerve of Hering)
    • Aortic arch receptor – a branch of the Vagus nerve (X CN) – aortic depressor nerve
  4. Center for Reflex
    • Medulla (Nucleus Tractus solitarius)
  5. Efferents
    • Sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons to heart and vasculature
    • Most sensitive to pulsatile pressure: They work to maintain BP in the range of mean BP, but it is the changes in the pressure they are the most sensitive to. 
    • The threshold for excitation: 50 mmHg
    • Maximal activity: 180 mmHg
  6. Responses when one carotid sinus is isolated and perfused and the other baroreceptors are denervated
    • Perfusion pressure <30mm Hg:no response
    • 70–110mm Hg: the linear relationship between perfusion pressure and the fall in systemic BP and HR
    • >150mm Hg: no further increase in response to the degree of inhibition of the sympathetic nerve is maximal.

questions.text: An elderly man is being evaluated for constipation and the finding seen on imaging studies is given in the image below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, an elderly man presenting with constipation, along with a barium enema image showing the "bird of prey" sign, is highly suggestive of sigmoid volvulus. 

This radiological sign, observed during the barium enema study, represents smooth tapered narrowing at the point of torsion of the sigmoid colon, looking like a hooked beak.

Sigmoid volvulus is a cause of large bowel obstruction and occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon. Symptoms include constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea, and/or vomiting. The onset may be acute or chronic. It occurs more commonly in patients with chronic constipation.

X-ray of the abdomen shows a large, dilated loop of the colon, often with a few air-fluid levels. Specific signs include the coffee bean sign/bent inner tube sign, Frimann-Dahl sign(three dense lines converge towards the site of obstruction), and the absence of rectal gas. CT may reveal a large gas-filled loop without haustral markings, forming a closed-loop obstruction.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: Which of the following features is more in favour of delirium?

choices.text: Occurs gradually over a period of time

questions.solution:
Fluctuating course is suggestive of delirium. 

Characteristic presentation of delirium:

  • Acute onset
  • Brief duration - usually days to weeks
  • Decline in the level of consciousness.
  • Fluctuating course - unpredictable fluctuations in severity and other clinical manifestations
  • Sundowning - worsening of symptoms at night
  • Rapid improvement - when the underlying cause is treated
  • Other characteristics include asterixis, carphologia (picking movements on cover sheets and clothes)
  • More commonly associated with visual hallucinations

questions.text: The X-ray image of a child with muscle weakness and failure to thrive is attached below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with the above X-ray image shows fraying and cupping of the metaphysis, suggestive of rickets.

Radiological features in rickets:

  • Fraying (Widening and irregularity of the growth plate)
  • Cupping (Concavity of the metaphysis)
  • Splaying at metaphysis (widening of metaphyseal ends)
  • Generalized rarefaction

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: A 47-year-old housewife presented with recurrent attacks of asthma and pain and numbness along the distribution of the median and ulnar nerve. Her serology was positive for pANCA. Further evaluation is unlikely to reveal which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of asthma, mononeuritis multiplex, and pANCA positivity is suggestive of Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis). It affects small to medium-sized arteries. 

Laboratory investigations will show peripheral blood eosinophilia. Some patients may be positive for pANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies). Histopathology will show the presence of necrotizing vasculitis, tissue eosinophilia, and extravascular granulomas.

Histopathology of ANCA associated vasculitides can be remembered as:

  • Microscopic polyangiitis: necrotizing vasculitis
  • Wegener's granulomatosis: necrotizing vasculitis with granulomas
  • Churg Strauss syndrome: necrotizing vasculitis with extravascular granulomas and eosinophilia

questions.text: The period between the first possible point of detection and the usual time of diagnosis is _______
questions.solution:
The period between the first possible point of detection and the usual time of diagnosis is called lead time.

Lead time refers to the benefit obtained through screening and refers to the time frame between the initial detection of a condition through early diagnosis compared to diagnosis through alternative methods.

Screening time is the time difference between the first point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis. Screening must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis.

Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection in a host and the maximal infectivity of that host.

Serial interval is the gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case. The term serial interval is used in an outbreak of disease.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and regional lymphadenopathy, following a scratch from his pet kitten. His lymph node biopsy specimen was examined with Warthin-Starry staining; the findings are shown in the given image. What is the causative organism of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever and lymphadenopathy after a cat scratch and the above image shows the black short rod-shaped bacilli arranged in chains or clumps, suggestive of cat scratch disease, This condition is caused by Bartonella henselae.

Cat scratch disease presents as a febrile illness with lymphadenopathy following a cat scratch. Patients present with a painless papule or pustule at the site of the scratch and lymph node enlargement and can be suppurative. The disease is usually self resolving. However, it can be treated with azithromycin only in patients who have severe complications.

questions.text: What is the net ATP yield in the beta-oxidation of a straight-chain fatty acid having 2N carbon atoms?
questions.solution:
A straight-chain fatty acid comprising of 2N carbon atoms will undergo [(2N ÷ 2) -1] = (N-1) cycles of beta-oxidation and produce N number of acetyl CoA.

Each acetyl CoA will undergo TCA cycle, producing 10 ATP. On the other hand, each cycle of beta-oxidation also produces 1 FADH2 and 1 NADH generating 1.5 ATP and 2.5 ATP respectively. Therefore (N-1) cycles of beta-oxidation will produce (N-1) FADH2 and (N-1) NADH.

The energetics of β-oxidation of a straight-chain fatty acid comprising of 2N carbon atoms can be summarized as follows:

Intermediate produced ATP yield per molecule Total number produced Total ATP
FADH2 1.5 N-1 1.5(N-1)
NADH 2.5 N-1 2.5(N-1)
Acetyl CoA 10 N 10N
Total ATP 1.5(N-1) +2.5(N-1) +10N =(14N-4)   
ATP used in activation - 2
Net ATP yield  (14N-4) -2 = 14N-6 

So, the net ATP yield after beta-oxidation of a straight-chain fatty acid having 2N carbon atoms will be (14N-4) - 2 = (14N- 6)We must keep in mind that during the initial activation of fatty acids (conversion of fatty acid to fatty acyl CoA), 2 ATP is utilized.

This formula can be used to calculate net ATP yield from a straight-chain fatty acid having an even number of carbon atoms. For example,

Net ATP yield from beta-oxidation of palmitic acid (16 carbon) will be 106.

Calculation: Here, 2N = 16 i.e, N = 8 . Therefore net ATP yield = (14x8 - 6) = 112-6 = 106

questions.solution:
The above diagram depicts the "rule of halves", which shows the distribution of hypertension in the community. The number 2 in this diagram denotes normotensive subjects.

questions.text: A 24-year-old professional football player was tackled hard during a match. He complains of severe pain in the left upper abdomen. On examination, his BP is 100/74 mm Hg and there is tenderness and crepitus over the left 10th and 11th ribs. He also complains of pain over the left shoulder when pressure is applied over the left upper abdominal quadrant. This sign is called:
questions.solution:
Kehr sign refers to referred pain in the tip of the left shoulder when firm pressure is applied over the left upper quadrant. It is also elicited by raising the left leg.

It is seen in the case of hemoperitoneum, especially due to splenic injury. It occurs due to the collection of blood below the diaphragm and irritation of the phrenic nerve. 

Option A: Ballance sign is also seen in splenic injury. It is an area of percussive dullness in the left upper quadrant due to the coagulation of blood from the injured spleen.

Option B: Cullen sign refers to periumbilical bruising in cases of hemoperitoneum, especially those of pancreatic origin. 

Option D: Grey Turner sign refers to bluish discolouration around flanks in case of hemoperitoneum especially acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding basal cell carcinoma?

choices.text: Nodular is the most common type
Most commonly seen over the neck
Only punch biopsy is used for diagnosis

questions.solution:
The most common form of BCC (60%) is the nodular variant. 

Other types of BCC are:

  • Superficial BCC- typically appears on the trunk as a pink or erythematous plaque with a thin pearly border
  • Infiltrative BCC
  • Pigmented variant of nodular BCC
  • Morpheaform variant - is an uncommon variant and is the most aggressive form
  • Fibroepithelioma of Pinkus

Option B: Patients with BCC show excellent prognosis with 100% survival rates for cases that have not spread to other sites.

Option C: Most of the basal cell carcinoma occurs on the face above the line joining the corner of the mouth and lobule of the ear.

Option D: Depending upon the type of lesion, a shave, punch, or exicision biopsy can be used to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: The Reynolds-Braude phenomenon is shown by:
questions.solution:
The Reynolds-Braude phenomenon is shown by Candida albicans.

If a few colonies of Candida albicans are inoculated in serum, the yeast cells start to form elongations called germ tubes within 2 hours, when kept at 37 °C. This is called the Reynold Braude phenomenon.

The image given below shows germ tube formation seen in candida species.

Candida is the most common cause of opportunistic mycoses in the world. Morphologically, they are yeast-like fungi. They exist as yeast and pseudohyphae (buds do not separate from parent cells) and true hyphae forms.

Candida appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. On Sabouraud dextrose agar, they appear as off-white pasty colonies. Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

The image below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores.

After incubation on CHROMagar for 1–4 days, colonies are seen: Candida albicans colonies appear green, as shown below; Candida glabrata colonies appear dark purple; and Candida parapsilosis colonies have a pinkish hue.

The most common species implicated in candidal infections are C. albicans, C. parapsilosis, and C. glabrata.  Vaginal mucosal invasion by the organism causes vulvovaginitis, marked by pruritus and vaginal discharge. A white pseudomembranous patchy lesion called thrush can occur on the tongue, lips, or gums.

The image given below shows oral thrush.

Immunocompromised individuals are at an increased risk of systemic candidiasis, which includes candidal endocarditis and urinary tract infections.

Mucocutaneous manifestations are managed with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: What does Ribot’s law deal with?
questions.solution:
Ribot's law deals with retrograde amnesia.

During incidents of retrograde amnesia, most recently acquired memories are the most vulnerable to disruption from brain damage. This temporal gradation of retrograde amnesia that preferentially spares the more distant memories is known as Ribot's law.

E.g: If an incident causing retrograde amnesia occurs at 30 years of age, the memories acquired at 25 years of age may be more severely affected than those memories acquired at 20 years of age or earlier.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain and vomiting. He has a history of frequent urinary infections. On CT scan, a horseshoe kidney was seen. Which of the following prevents the ascent of this organ?
questions.solution:
The inferior mesenteric artery prevents the ascent of the horseshoe kidney. 

The horseshoe kidney is usually found at the level of the lower lumbar vertebrae. Its ascent is halted by the root of the inferior mesenteric artery. The connecting isthmus of the horseshoe kidney may be present either in front or behind the aorta and the inferior vena cava. 

Pelvic kidney: Occasionally, one kidney fails to ascend. It is usually found in the pelvis near the common iliac artery.

questions.text: Within how many minutes of vaginal penetration should ejaculation regularly occur to diagnose a patient with premature ejaculation?
questions.solution:
Premature (early) ejaculation is diagnosed when the patient regularly ejaculates within 1 minute of vaginal penetration. A common reason for this disorder is performance anxiety leading to sympathetic arousal.

Such men persistently or recurrently achieve orgasm and ejaculation before they wish to. 

Can be classified as:

Mild 30 sec to 1 min
Moderate 15 sec to 30 sec
Severe <15 sec

Management:

  • Pharmacological: SSRI- Paroxetine and Dapoxetine (cause delayed ejaculation)
  • Non-pharmacological: using techniques such as Squeeze technique, Start-stop technique and sensate focusing 

Note: DSM-5 refers only to vaginal penetration in its diagnostic criteria, whereas ICD-11 includes other relevant sexual stimulation also.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about cadaveric rigidity in contrast to cadaveric spasm?
  1. It is due to the depletion of ATP
  2. Muscles respond to electrical stimuli
  3. It happens instantaneously after death
  4. It is an antemortem phenomenon
  5. It indicates time since death
questions.solution:
Cadaveric rigidity is also known as rigor mortis. It is due to the depletion of ATP and indicates time since death. Muscle stiffening is not marked and can be overcome by moderate force. The rigor starts occurring 1-2 hours after death (postmortem nature) and muscles do not respond to electrical stimuli.

Cadaveric spasm / instantaneous rigor/ cataleptic rigidity/ death clutch is a phenomenon where a group of muscles in a state of contraction at the time of death remains contracted after death until molecular death occurs.

Cadaveric spasm is an antemortem phenomenon and occurs immediately after death. There is no stage of primary relaxation. It is seen in cases of deaths coupled with emotional disturbances like:

  • In cases of excitement, fear, severe pain
  • Exhaustion at the time of death
  • Cerebral hemorrhage
  • Injury to the nervous system
  • Drowning
  • Strychnine poisoning

Examples:

  • In case of drowning, weeds and grass caught in hand during struggle remain firmly grasped even after death. This indicates that the person was alive when entering the water
  • In case of suicides, weapons remain firmly grasped in the hand

questions.text: A patient presents to you with ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis. Which of the following structures marked is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis is suggestive of Horner's syndrome which can be caused by damage to the cervical sympathetic trunk (marked B). 

In the given image:

  1. Vagus nerve
  2. Cervical sympathetic trunk
  3. Phrenic nerve
  4. Recurrent laryngeal nerve

The cervical part of the sympathetic trunk lies anterior to longus colli and longus capitis muscles (enclosed in prevertebral fascia) and posterior to the common carotid artery. The sympathetic trunk lies outside the carotid sheath.

Related Pearl: Horner's syndrome

Horner's Syndrome:

Horner's syndrome occurring due to occulo-sympathetic paresis is characterized by the classic triad of:

  • Mild ptosis (due to paralysis of Muller's muscle).
  • Miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae).
  • Reduced ipsilateral sweating (anhydrosis).

Other features include:

  • Mild enophthalmos,
  • Loss of cilio-spinal reflex,
  • Heterochromia, i.e., the ipsilateral iris is lighter in colour,
  • Pupil is slow to dilate, and there occurs slight elevation of lower eyelid.

Cocaine test (2% to 4%): Small pupils fail to dilate in Horner's syndrome.

In congenital Horner's syndrome, the additional features seen are heterochromia iridis and unilateral straight hair.

questions.text: Which of the following is the rate-limiting enzyme of the fatty acid synthesis pathway?
questions.solution:
Acetyl CoA carboxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the fatty acid synthesis pathway.

Acetyl CoA carboxylase converts acetyl CoA into malonyl CoA, the first step of de novo fatty acid synthesis. It is an allosteric enzyme activated by citrate in the well-fed state. Acetyl CoA carboxylase requires the following: 

  • NADPH as the reducing equivalent 
  • Biotin is a coenzyme needed by carboxylases
  • ATP for energy
  • Manganese (Mn2+)
  • HCO3- as the carbon donor

questions.text: You are conducting the autopsy of a patient who passed away following myocardial infarction. What would be the earliest light microscopic change that can be observed in the heart of this patient?
questions.solution:
The earliest light microscopic change that can be observed in the heart of this patient is the waviness of myocardial fibres. This is seen within ½-4 hours at the border of the infarct.

These changes are a result of the forceful contractions of viable fibres. The contractions cause stretching and buckling of immediately adjacent, noncontractile dead fibres.

Myocyte vacuolization or myocytolysis may also be seen in the infarct margins. It is due to the accumulation of salt and water in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Such myocytes are viable but poorly contractile.

The image below shows microscopic features of myocardial infarction showing wavy myocardial fibres. There are wavy fibres that are elongated and narrow, as compared with normal fibres. The widened spaces between the dead fibres contain edema fluid and scattered neutrophils.

questions.text: Which of the following genes is the most commonly implicated in hereditary pulmonary arterial hypertension?
questions.solution:

The BMPR2 receptor is involved in the regulation of growth, differentiation, and apoptosis of pulmonary artery endothelial and smooth muscle cells. Due to the mutation, there is enhanced proliferation and reduced apoptosis of vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells leading to pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: In Paget-Schroetter syndrome which of the following structure is affected?
questions.solution:
In Paget-Schroetter syndrome, the subclavian vein is affected.

Compression of subclavian vein between anterior scalene, clavicle, and the first rib can produce axillary-subclavian vein thrombosis. It results in severe upper extremity pain and swelling,  that is exaggerated by exercise.

Activities such as throwing, swimming, and weightlifting can cause microtrauma of the venous intima that initiates thrombus formation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is obsessed with a famous Bollywood actor. She convinced herself that he is deeply in love with her and stood outside his home for hours believing that he was communicating his desire for her by waving and moving the curtains. Which of the following is false regarding this disorder?

choices.text: It is referred as an erotomanic delusion
It is also known as psychose passionelle
Patient says they fell in love with a person of higher status first

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of De Clerambault syndrome. In this, the patients will generally describe that a person of higher status had fallen in love with them (patient) and made advances first.

It is also referred to as an erotomanic type of delusional disorder or psychose passionelle.

Stalking may be observed and they most often persecute their targets by unwanted communications.

De Clérambault in his paper in which he described the syndrome referenced a patient he had counseled who was obsessed with British monarch George V, she had stood outside Buckingham palace for hours believing that the king was communicating his desire for her by moving the curtains. 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. He was recently diagnosed with diabetes mellitus. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly. His liver microscopy on Prussian blue staining is given below. What is the mode of inheritance of his disease?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of hereditary hemochromatosis. It is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder that involves the HFE gene.

Hemochromatosis is characterized by excessive iron accumulation that results in tissue damage. It consists of a triad of:

  • Micronodular cirrhosis
  • Bronzing of the skin
  • Diabetes mellitus

Diagnosis is by elevated levels of serum ferritin, serum iron, transferrin saturation, and confirmation by a gene assay.

Note: Autosomal recessive disorders include almost all inborn errors of metabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following findings would you expect to see in patients with median nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
A positive pen test is seen in median nerve palsy. It tests the abductor pollicis brevis. The hand must remain flat with palm facing upwards; a pen is held above the palm and the patient is asked to touch the pen with his thumb - Positive sign is the inability to touch the pen.

Tests used in ulnar nerve injuries include:

  • Wartenberg's sign - Due to weakness of the palmar interossei muscles and unopposed action of the extensor digiti minimi, there is involuntary abduction of the little finger.
  • Positive Egawa's test - Due to weakness of dorsal interossei, side to side movements of middle finger is weak.
  • Positive book test or Froment's sign - Due to weakness of adductor pollicis muscle, adduction of thumb is lost. When asked to hold a book, patient tries to hold the book by using flexor pollicis longus muscle. This produces flexion at inter-phalangeal joint while holding the book.

 

  • Card test - Inability to hold a card between the fingers due to loss of adduction by palmar interossei muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids has an imino ring?
questions.solution:
Proline is an amino acid with an imino ring.

The distinctive cyclic structure of the side chain of proline gives it exceptional conformational rigidity as compared to other amino acids. Hence, proline plays a major role in collagen stability.

questions.text: Which of the following depicts the critical path in the project plan shown below?
questions.solution:
The critical path in the critical path method (CPM) is the longest path denoted by path 4 (7 days) in the plan shown above.

Any delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: A patient presents with chronic back ache and hearing loss. His X-ray spine is given below. Which of the following is not a complication of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray showing ivory vertebrae is suggestive of Paget's disease. Paget’s disease of the bone increases the risk of osteosarcoma and not osteochondroma.

Complications of Paget's disease are:

  • Malignancy
    • Osteosarcoma (most common)
    • Fibrosarcoma
    • Chondrosarcoma
    • Sarcoma of myeloid and mesenchymal element
  • Increased risk of fractures due to decreased bone strength
  • Osteoarthritis
  • Bony overgrowth leading to spinal stenosis and nerve compression
  • High output cardiac failure due to increased blood flow to skeletal bones
  • Hypercalcemia in patients with prolonged immobilization
  • 2nd, 5th, 7th, and 8th cranial nerve palsies
  • Deafness due to nerve compression > otosclerosis

Acanthocyte or spur cells are seen in anaemia of liver disease. These cells are characterized by only a few spicules of varying sizes that project from the cell surface at irregular intervals.

Conditions where acanthocytes can be seen include:

  • Severe liver disease
  • Abetalipoproteinemia
  • Post splenectomy
  • Hyposplenism

The image given below shows a peripheral smear with acanthoctye.

Echinocytes or burr cells are seen in anaemia of renal disease. These cells are characterized by smaller, regularly spaced projections, smoothly rounded crenulations which are uniform in shape and distribution compared to acanthocytes.

Conditions where echinocytes can be seen include:

  • Anaemia of renal disease (uremia)
  • In premature infants, after exchange transfusion
  • Storage artefact

The image given below shows a peripheral smear with echinocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria shows Kanagawa phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Kanagawa phenomenon is shown by Vibrio parahaemolyticus. It refers to hemolysis occuring when the bacteria are inoculated on Wagatsuma agar.

Pathogenic strains of V. parahaemolyticus are hemolytic, while non-pathogenic strains are non-hemolytic. This phenomenon occurs due to a heat-stable hemolysin.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma?

choices.text: It can progress to a tumor resembling DLBCL
The bone marrow involvement is rare
A strong association with EBV is seen

questions.solution:
Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL) is not associated with Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) infection.

In 3% to 5% of cases, this type transforms into a tumor resembling diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

A majority of patients are males, usually younger than 35 years of age, who typically present with cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Mediastinal and bone marrow involvement is rare.

This form of HL is more likely to recur than the classical subtypes, but the prognosis is excellent.

questions.text: "Tomcat urine"  is characteristically seen in ________
questions.solution:
Tomcat urine is characteristically seen in multiple carboxylase deficiency.

It is named so because of its peculiar odour.

questions.text: On which chromosome are HLA genes located?
questions.solution:
The genes encoding HLA molecules are clustered on a short arm of chromosome 6 (6p).

The function of MHC molecules is to display peptide fragments of protein antigens for recognition by antigen-specific T cells. In humans, the MHC molecules are called human leukocyte antigens (HLA) because they were initially detected on leukocytes by the binding of antibodies. The combination of HLA alleles in each individual is called the HLA haplotype.

The HLA system is highly polymorphic. Each individual’s HLA alleles differ from the other. It has to be checked before organ transplantation.

questions.text: A child with a violaceous, raised nodular skin lesion which on biopsy is found to be infiltrated by myeloblasts is likely suffering from which type of Acute myeloid leukemia (AML)?
questions.solution:
Nodular, violaceous skin lesion infiltrated with myeloblasts is descriptive of Chloroma otherwise known as extramedullary myeloblastoma or granulocytic(myeloid) sarcoma. Myeloid sarcomas are seen in AML subtypes M2, M4, M5a, and M5b.

“Chloroma” was coined due to the peculiar green color of the tumor caused by myeloperoxidase present in tumor cells.

These masses can occur in the absence of apparent bone marrow involvement and typically are associated with t(8;21) translocation. Chloromas also may be seen in the orbit and epidural space.

The main conditions that can cause bilateral orbital masses in children are idiopathic non granulomatous orbital inflammation, metastatic neuroblastoma, and myeloid sarcoma

questions.text: Bracket calcification on skull X-Ray is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Lipoma of the corpus callosum shows bracket calcification on skull X-ray.

Intracranial lipomas are most commonly located in the midline and are commonly associated with congenital malformations such as agenesis/dysgenesis of the corpus callosum. Pericallosal lipomas are classified into anteriorly located bulky tubulo-nodular type and posteriorly located ribbon-like curvilinear type. Imaging is the mainstay in the diagnosis of intracranial lipoma. 

The image below shows bracket calcification:

Option A: Tuberous sclerosis shows calcification of subependymal hamartomas in the wall of the ventricles.

Option B: Sturge Weber syndrome shows tram track calcification.

Option D: Meningioma on X-ray shows calcification hyperostosis and increased vascular markings, it is usually seen in the falx.

questions.text: Which of the following serotypes are present in the bivalent vaccine against the human papillomavirus?
questions.solution:
Serotypes 16 and 18 are present in the bivalent vaccine against the human papillomavirus (HPV). It is called Cervarix. Cervarix is given at 0, 1 and 6 months.

Gardasil/Silgard is the quadrivalent vaccine against HPV. It has serotypes 6, 11, 16 and 18 and is given at 0, 2 and 6 months.

Gardasil 9 is the nonavalent vaccine against HPV. It has serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and 58. In 2020 it has received an expanded indication which now includes the prevention of oropharyngeal and head and neck cancers.

questions.text: What does the Sin of Gomorrah refer to?
questions.solution:
Buccal coitus is also known as the sin of Gomorrah/ Coitus Per Os. The male genital organ is introduced into the mouth of another male or female.

Teeth marks or abrasions on the penis, semen in the respiratory tract/stomach could be the clues to diagnosis. Buccal swabs are useful for only up to 9 hours. Buccal coitus can lead to death by aspiration of semen or impaction of the penis in the hypopharynx.

Option A: Sodomy is anal intercourse between 2 males or between a male and a female. 

Option C: Incest is sexual intercourse between man and woman who are related by blood or a certain degree of blood relationship.

Option D: Bestiality is the sexual intercourse of a human being with a lower animal.

questions.text: The IVP imaging of a 30-year-old woman is given below. What is it diagnostic of?
questions.solution:
The given intravenous pyelogram is characteristic for medullary sponge kidney. It shows ectatic distal collecting ducts containing microcalcifications, which is called bouquet of flowers appearance. Dilated contrast-filled tubules within the renal medulla are also seen, which is known as paintbrush appearance. 

This is a developmental defect affecting the formation of collecting tubules and results in cystic dilatation of the medullary and papillary portions of collecting ducts.

questions.text: The presence of Kussmaul's sign in a patient is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Kussmaul's sign is indicative of restrictive cardiomyopathy.

Kussmaul's sign is a paradoxical rise or failure in the appropriate fall of jugular venous pressure (JVP) with inspiration. It is classically associated with constrictive pericarditis.

Normally, during inspiration, the JVP falls due to the negative intrathoracic pressure. When there is impairment in the expansion of the right ventricle or a raise in the right atrial pressure, there is a back pressure of blood in the jugular veins. This causes a paradoxical rise in the JVP during inspiration instead of a fall.

Kussmaul's sign can also be associated with:

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Right ventricular infarction
  • Advanced left ventricular systolic heart failure

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect concerning the drug in the image below?
questions.solution:
Propofol is not contraindicated in egg allergy patients.

Propofol is formulated as an oil-in-water emulsion, which contains soybean oil, glycerol, and egg lecithin. Usually, egg allergies are a reaction to egg white (egg albumin). But, propofol contains egg lecithin, which is extracted from egg yolk, and so, propofol is not necessarily contraindicated in patients with a history of egg allergy.

Propofol has been associated with life-threatening systemic infections because it decreases polymorphonuclear leukocyte chemotaxis, but not adherence phagocytosis and killing. It inhibits phagocytosis and killing of Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli.

Propofol is associated with hypertriglyceridemia which can predispose to pancreatitis.

It has antiemetic properties which help in reducing the incidence of post operative nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: A clinician is performing the following test on a patient with sciatic pain. Which sign is being elicited here?
questions.solution:
The image shows the examiner pressing the popliteal fossa of the patient to elicit sciatic pain. This is known as the Bowstring sign. 

Important tests for intervertebral disc prolapse:

1. Straight Leg Raising Test (SLRT) or Lasegue sign:

  • Done to assess nerve root irritation in the lumbosacral area. 
  • Patient is made to lie on the back with the head extended, with hips and legs in the neutral position.
  • Affected leg passively and slowly raised by the ankle with the knee fully extended
  • SLRT test negative if leg can be raised 80–90 degrees without pain
  • SLRT test positive if pain elicited between 30-60 or 70 degrees from horizontal
  • Pain should be radicular type and radiating to the back of the thigh or to the calf

2. Bragard test (sciatic stretch test or flip test):

  • Perform SLRT
  • When the patient experiences discomfort, the leg is lowered a little till the pain disappears
  • At this angle, the ankle is passively dorsiflexed
  • If pain is felt again at the back of the thigh or in the calf, the test is positive
  • Also called reinforcement positive or Bragard’s sign positive

3. Crossed SLRT (well-leg raising test or Fajersztajn sign):

  • SLRT is performed on the unaffected side
  • Pain felt on the affected side
  • Termed a contralateral positive SLRT or crossed SLRT positive
  • Very specific sign of root compression
  • Usually positive when there is severe compression due to a centrally located prolapse

4. Popliteal compression test or Bowstring sign:

  • Bowstring sign is more specific for disc prolapse than SLRT
  • Perform SLRT until the patient experiences sciatic pain
  • Without reducing the amount of lift, bend the knee to relax the sciatic nerve
  • Buttock pain is immediately relieved
  • The examiner then presses popliteal fossa to stretch the lateral popliteal nerve behind the lateral tibial condyle
  • Tightening of the nerve like a bowstring re-induces the pain  

5. Femoral stretch (reverse Lasegue test or Mackiewicz sign):

  • Patient lies prone
  • Examiner flexes the knee and the hip is passively extended
  • Test is positive if patient experiences anterior thigh pain
  • This test is usually positive for L2-L3 and L3-L4 (high lumbar) protrusions

questions.text: All of the following are true about maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY) except:

choices.text: MODY 4 is the most common form

questions.solution:
MODY 3 is the most common form of maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY), accounting for two-thirds of all the cases.

MODY is a monogenic form of diabetes mellitus that is transmitted in an autosomal dominant fashion. It affects young adults <25 years of age. There are a total of 11 types of MODY based on mutations involves. Some of the affected genes include:

  • Types 1,3,5: HNF (Hepatocyte nuclear transcription factor) mutation
  • Type 2: Glucokinase mutation
  • Type 4: IPF 1 (Insulin Promotor Factor-1) mutation

These mutations result in impaired glucose-induced insulin secretion resulting in insulinopenia.

questions.text: What type of joint is an incudostapedial joint?
questions.solution:
The incudostapedial joint is a ball and socket type of joint.

In ball and socket type of joints, the articular surfaces include a globular head (male surface) fitting into a cup-shaped socket (female surface). These joints are multi-axial and movements occur around a number of axes. Flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, medial rotation, lateral rotation, and circumduction, all occur quite freely. E.g., shoulder joint, hip joint, talocalcaneonavicular joint, and incudostapedial joint.

Note: The other joint between the incus and malleus (incudomalleolar joint) is a saddle joint.

questions.text: Which of the following situations does the red line in the following graph depict?
questions.solution:
The red line indicates an enzymatic reaction taking place in the presence of a competitive inhibitor.

The graph represents the enzymatic reaction velocity in relation to substrate concentration. The black line indicates the reaction taking place in the absence of any inhibitor.

In the presence of a competitive inhibitor, as indicated by the red line,

  • Vmax remains unchanged.
  • Km  is increased.

In the presence of a non-competitive inhibitor, as indicated by the blue line,

  • Vmax is decreased
  • Km remains unchanged

Note:

Suicide inhibitors are specialized substrate analogs. They contain a chemical group that can be transformed by the target enzyme. After binding to the active site of the enzyme, catalysis by the enzyme generates a highly reactive group that forms a covalent bond and blocks the function of the enzyme.

questions.text: A baby delivered at home was born with ambiguous genitalia. The parents could not identify the sex of the child. The baby was diagnosed with congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is this child most likely to have?
questions.solution:
This child is most likely to have a 21-hydroxylase deficiency as it is the most common enzyme deficiency implicated in congenital adrenal hyperplasia. The second most common is 11 beta-hydroxylase deficiency.

 

21-hydroxylase enzyme hydroxylates progesterone and 17-hydroxyprogesterone to yield 11-deoxycorticosterone and 11-deoxycortisol, respectively. They help in the synthesis of aldosterone and cortisol. Therefore, the deficiency of this enzyme leads to the deficiencies of aldosterone and cortisol.

Also, the accumulated steroid precursors are diverted into the pathway for androgen (testosterone) production.

Clinical profile in 21-hydroxylase deficiency:

  • Aldosterone deficiency: Salt-wasting crises (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis)
  • Cortisol deficiency: Hypoglycemia, hyperpigmentation (due to increased ACTH production), weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, and shock
  • Androgens excess: Virilization of females and precocious puberty in males

questions.text: A young lady who presented with oligomenorrhea and infertility is diagnosed with PCOS. Mutation of which of the following genes can cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Mutation of the CYP21 gene can cause polycystic ovarian syndrome.

The gene for 21-hydroxylase (CYP21) is located in the short arm of chromosome 6. Heterozygosity of the gene has been linked to the development of PCOS. Defects in this gene also lead to congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

PCOS and PCOD are two different diseases. In PCOD, the ovaries begin to release immature eggs, resulting in hormonal imbalances and enlarged ovaries, whereas in PCOS, it is an endocrine disorder that causes the ovaries to create excess androgens, making the eggs prone to cyst formation. However, unlike with PCOD, these cysts will not be expelled and will instead accumulate in the ovaries.

questions.text: Retinoblastoma arises from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Retinoblastoma (also called glioma retinae) arises from the neurosensory retina. It is a proliferation of neural cells that have failed to evolve normally.

Tumours are composed of small basophilic cells (retinoblasts), with large hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm.

It is of 4 types:

  1. Endophytic (into the vitreous) with seeding of tumor cells throughout the eye
  2. Exophytic (into the subretinal space) leading to retinal detachment
  3. Mixed type
  4. Retinocytoma: retina may be diffusely infiltrated

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. The radiograph of his pelvis is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph of the patient's pelvis following a road traffic accident reveals upward and lateral dislocation of the left femoral head, accompanied by an obscured lesser trochanter, indicating a posterior dislocation of the left hip.

Posterior hip dislocation is commonly seen following dashboard injuries and the patient presents with flexion, adduction, and internal rotation deformity of the lower limb.

Radiological findings:

  • Loss of continuity of acetabulum with the femoral head (break in Shenton's line)
  • Upward and lateral displacement of the femoral head
  • The femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • The lesser trochanter is not visualized as the thigh is internally rotated
  • Femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen 

The image below shows posterior dislocation with disruption of Shenton's line:

Treatment:

An early reduction should be done as the risk of osteonecrosis and subsequent osteoarthritis increases with time. 

Closed reduction under sedation or general anaesthesia is done in most cases. If there is an associated femoral neck fracture, a closed reduction should not be attempted as it can lead to the displacement of the femoral neck and disrupt the blood supply to the femoral head.

In closed reduction the following steps are done:

The pelvis is kept in a steady position and traction is applied in line of the femur with the knee flexed at 90 degrees. The hip is then flexed maintaining the traction along with internal rotation and adduction. This is called Allis' maneuver. The below image describes this technique: 

 Other methods of closed reduction include - Stimson's maneuver, East Baltimore lift maneuver, and Bigelow's maneuver. 

 

After reduction, the stability of the hip is tested by flexing the hip to 90 degrees, and a longitudinal and posteriorly directed force is applied. While performing this the joint is monitored in an image intensifier to look for any signs of subluxation. In case of evidence of subluxation or any significant fractures then surgical repair should be done. If there is a delay in surgical correction, skeletal traction with a distal femoral traction pin can be done.

If there is damage to the acetabulum, or intervening structures between the femoral head and the acetabular surface are present - open reduction can be considered. 

Early complications:

  • Sciatic nerve injury - It can be damaged in 10-20% of the cases
  • Vascular injury - Superior gluteal artery tear can occur
  • Concurrent femoral shaft fracture - When both occur together hip dislocation may be missed

Late complications:

  • Osteonecrosis of the femoral head
  • Myositis ossificans 
  • Secondary osteoarthritis 
  • Recurrent instability

questions.text: Which is the best parameter to analyze hypoxic hypoxia?

choices.text: Partial pressure of CO2 in arterial blood (Paco2)
Partial pressure of O2 in arterial blood (Pao2)

questions.solution:
Hypoxic hypoxia is characterized by low partial pressure of O2 in arterial blood (Pao2), while other parameters like partial pressure of CO2 in arterial blood (Paco2) may remain normal.

Ventilation–Perfusion Imbalance:

  • The patchy ventilation–perfusion imbalance is the most common cause of hypoxic hypoxia or hypoxemia.
  • If alveoli are not ventilated but perfusion is present - blood passing through that alveoli remains unoxygenated.
  • When this unoxygenated blood mixes with blood from normal or overventilated alveoli, there is a right to left shunt created.
  • This results in reduced partial pressure of O2 in arterial blood  (PaO2) i.e., hypoxemia and consequently hypoxia.

Note:

  • Hypoxemia can be defined as a condition where arterial oxygen tension or partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) is below normal.
  • Hypoxia is defined as the reduction of oxygen supply at the tissue level, which is not measured directly by a laboratory value.

Scenario 1:

  • Generally, the presence of hypoxemia suggests hypoxia i.e. if there is less oxygen in blood, O2 supply to tissues will also be reduced.
  • But, in case of cyanide poisoning, there is hypoxia in the absence of hypoxemia, i.e., arterial O2 content is normal but tissues are not able to utilize it because cyanide interferes with aerobic metabolism in the tissues.

Scenario 2:

  • Hypoxia may not be present in patients with hypoxemia if the patient compensates for a low PaO2 by increasing oxygen delivery. This is typically achieved by increasing cardiac output (by raising the heart rate) or decreasing tissue oxygen consumption.
  • Nevertheless, hypoxemia is definitely the most common cause of tissue hypoxia, and the correct diagnosis should be made because it is readily treatable.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a history of multiple sclerosis comes to the hospital. She describes an electric shock–like sensation radiating down the back into the legs. What is the name of this sign?
questions.solution:
An electric shock-like sensation radiating down the back into the legs is called Lhermitte's sign. It is associated with multiple sclerosis.

It is induced typically by flexion or other movements of the neck. Lhermitte’s sign can also occur simultaneously with other disorders of the cervical spinal cord like cervical spondylosis.

Option A: Uhthoff ’s phenomenon refers to the unilateral visual blurring that may occur during a hot shower or with physical exercise. It is an exacerbation of the symptoms of multiple sclerosis due to heat.

Option C: Stransky's sign is a clinical sign in which vigorous abduction followed by the sudden release of the little toe causes an extensor plantar reflex. It is seen in pyramidal tract lesions.

Option D: Cornell's sign is a clinical sign in which scratching along the inner side of the extensor hallucis longus tendon elicits an extensor plantar reflex. It is seen in pyramidal tract lesions.
